author: PapaPupp
review: After over 17 years with a Steam account I haven't felt the need to leave a review until now. My wife and I are about 4 hours in and this game has already totally blown us away. I honestly can't remember the last time a game made me smile and laugh this much while also being totally engrossed in the gameplay. The split screen takes a little getting used to at first and then you don't even notice it.Just an absolute joy to play and hands-down the best couch coop game I have played in about two and a half decades of PC gaming (yikes I'm getting old...).Buy it, you won't regret it! 10/10!!

author: Kris.vdv
review: Started playing this today with my daughter, we couldn’t stop and played for 3.5 hours straight. And then afterwards she couldn’t stop talking about it :). Only once every couple of years, a beautiful and brilliant story-driven couch co-op like this one is made. An instant classic.

author: xenoprobe
review: Best neglectful parent simulator, ever.I purchased this game specifically to play with my significant other. While we expected it to be good, It Takes Two, the sophomore effort from developer, Hazelight, impressed us so much, it is now the benchmark for which I will measure future co-op game experiences. We simply lost count of how many charming moments we encountered whilst playing.I could go on and on, but, the selling points of this game are best experienced for yourself.Each painstakingly detailed level in this title offers you unique gameplay mechanics that are never recycled. Communication and cooperation are a must, as well as decent twitch response reflexes. Various mini-games are scattered around the environment, and give you a slight reprieve from your main objective, only to get your competitive juices flowing. (sore losers need not apply!) Controls are tight and responsive, and the camera does a decent job of keeping track of the action. However, those who suffer from motion sickness may occasionally become disoriented or even nauseated due to the mandatory split screen. Overall, this is a very high quality, one of a kind experience that could only be produced as a labor of love. Pick this one up, play it with someone special, and let the hilarity ensue.Highly recommended.

author: dead scum enjoyer
review: Amazing game that I love to play, but the boyfriend that I was playing it with broke up with me a few days after playing this game. A game that's about fixing your relationship.10/10 game.0/10 in my heart.edit: why do people find this funny i wasn't kiddingEdit # 2: It has been 7 months since I had originally played this game. What was originally a game of heartbreak and painful memories, I had managed to find it someone new to play with. While this game had terrible memories, I had decided that a game such as this was undeserving of them, and thus created new memories with another special person in my life.The game is remarkable, with good writing, and amazing gameplay, and it is deserving of the buy. Each level is crafted with amazing detail, and all of the mini-games are just as fun as the main game itself. Don't let bad memories keep you down, and instead create happier ones. Live your life, ya'll.

author: crossy mc face
review: This game was so breathtakingly amazing that I am genuinely sad that it is over.My 6yo daughter and I loved every moment and not only did the chracters grow to love each other again, but I watched my daughter grow over the last few months from trying her best to play it with me, to absolutely blindsiding me with how many of the puzzles and platfroming she now pulls off effortlessly. When it ended it was So so so bitter sweet. It had been our thing to do when we had time together lately and now we have no idea what will fill that void of relaxing gaming with my little girl. She rushed to tell my wife we had finished it and she was so proud! But then when she returned to the study, she asked me if I could find a game just like this one...but one does not exist!I have never had a game in the last 25 years or so effect my heart so much as this game, it remind me of when I was young, discovering Shining Force 2 for the first time!The game play, the MASSIVE amount of genres touched on, the secrets, the easter eggs, THE MINIGAMES! The story, amazing!I have never played anything like this. As the final cut scene played my daughter said, "you know daddy, mummy would probably be crying at this bit", with tears in my eyes I turned to my daughter and said with a smile, "Yeh, she might, but not me hey, Id never cry" It was at this point she noticed my tears, she smiled and gave me a big hug. Now tell me what game could achieve that.10/10 a fan for life. Absolutely speechless on how good this game is!

author: CringeWriter
review: 22.12.2021."It takes two" is a co-op only game. Naturally since I’m not able to clone myself yet, I had to actually go out there and find another person to play this game with me. And wouldn’t you know it, I remember that I was married. Seeing how this game is about a husband and wife, I figured it would be appropriate to ask my wife to be my co-op partner, for better or worse. Anyway, my wife insisted that, since she has played every single minute of this game with me, that she be a part of this review. Hello, dear!Yup, the story is honestly really cute and both of us really wanted to see it through until the end. Sure there were parts that we didn’t like but I think it’s safe to say that both of us had a grand time going through the entire game.And she isn't kidding. The game isn’t too challenging for veteran platform players, such as myself, who are basically more comfortable with jumping in games than they are with communicating with actual people. The game pretty much DEMANDS that you have played A LOT OF platformers, LIKE A LOT. It’s hard to deny this. Like I said, the platforming wasn’t too challenging for me but it was waiting for a player that just isn’t as skilled with these types of games. Quite honestly, I think I was more mad at the game than at my wife. I mean, the game clearly wants husbands and wives to play together, right? So, why not make it a little less challenging for newbies? Even though platforming was a huge part of the game, the game dipped it’s toes into almost all other genres. On almost every single level, not only will there be a new environment to navigate through but both players will receive level-specific power ups. Which ones did you like honey?Honestly, I liked almost all of them, especially because you always had to rely on the other player to get through a section. No matter how cool my own power was, it was useless if the other player wasn’t assisting. It’s one of this game’s best features in my opinion.Again, I liked almost all of them. I appreciate when the game keeps things fresh with the environments. With that said, the clock tower level and the music level can kiss my a**.Well, fortunately, the game is very forgiving with it’s checkpoints so we never spent too much time stuck on anything. What did you think of the mini-games? Personally, I thought they were a huge waste of time.Well, maybe if they actually did something for the game, but it’s just like you said, they were distractions. Glad you enjoyed them, though. Any favorites?So, honey, in your own honest opinion. Would you recommend this game to other couples?She is being too generous. I was a real ♥♥♥♥ to her during some harder ( ) sections. As for me, this is an easy recommendation. Not only is this game constantly changing the gameplay and keeping everything fresh but the way how co-op is absolutely essential in order to progress is what really sealed the deal for me.Now as for buying this game, it’s a bit expensive at full price. Fortunately, you can buy a month or two with EA Play and finish it that way, which I think is a better option. Regardless of how you get the game, I think it’s definitely worth playing. Any last comments, honey?(rolls eyes) I’m soooooo looking forward to that.

author: Mz Cookies
review: Undoubtedly, It Takes Two is a coop masterpiece. Its extremely diverse gameplay is held to such a high standard from beginning to end. The visuals are stunning, the story is immersive, and the sound is memorable. Developed by Hazelight studios, the same developers that brought us the famous coop title "A Way Out", they prove once more, that the use of split screens can have a place in modern gaming.+ Exceptionally diverse, smooth and genre-bending gameplay.+ Detailed, gorgeous and bright visuals across a myriad of differing environments.+ Simple but relatable and charismatic story about marital woes.+ Copious interactive environments and mini-games to explore.+ Logical, simple puzzles to conquer.+ Friend's pass that allows friends to play the game for free with a player that owns the full copy of the game.- Remarkably easy with an awfully forgiving respawn system.Players are introduced to the dissolving relationship of Cody and May, an unhappily married couple. We witness their arguing and inability to get along, ultimately leading to the decision to tell their child about their looming divorce. This is where the craziness begins and where reality as we know it soon begins to evaporate. This chain of events ultimately causes the couple to transform into Rose's toy dolls. The two try their best to identify a possible cause for this sudden transformation and also brainstorm solutions. They do not get much time to consider their predicament before Dr Hakim "Book of Love" abruptly makes his appearance. With Rose's best interests at heart, he sets out almost obnoxiously optimistically to relight Cody and May's love. He sends them on many incredulous and bizarre quests with the goal of reigniting their passion, with each area forcing them to collaborate and understand each other to proceed. Driven by their desire to revert back to their own bodies and after working closely together, they slowly begin to see the value in each other. Realising each other's unique skills and passions which causes many old memories to arise, but is it enough to awaken their long lost love?The task of describing the gameplay of It Takes Two is a difficult one. It is perhaps one of the most varied, dynamic, and energetic games I have come across. Featuring too many genres to name, it masters everything it includes. Every level is a rollercoaster and seamlessly transitions through each element. From a top down section similar to , a fighting short scene akin to , and  gravity fuelled puzzles, reminiscent of  Each area almost feels and looks like a brand new game, it was just that unique. New weapons and abilities are constantly introduced throughout the game. These elements are only ever used temporarily, before being replaced with something else. Shoot down foes, reduce or enlarge your size at the click of a button, defy gravity with magnetic boots, slice enemies with a sickle and use a magnet to grip onto surfaces (or your partner). This is only a small selection of the differing aspects experienced throughout the game and the creative ideas do not stop here. Players also get to swing, fly, grapple and grind rails through the air with ease. Ride frogs, deep sea creatures, make friends and enemies, verse your partner in a variety of minigames and work together to solve puzzles. I was aptly blown away with the amount of sheer creativity seen in each and every level. Whilst the title shares a lot of similarities with other renowned games, the differing concepts are seamlessly combined, providing for a fresh and engaging experience.  It Takes Two is not designed to be difficult in any way. The whole premise is constructed so players glide through the levels with ease, never succumbing to fatigue or feeling bored, with constant new stimuli introduced to grasp players' attention. Despite this, it is important to note that with this in mind, the game is exceptionally and purposefully simple. You will die countless times, only to be respawned almost exactly in the same spot. Being hit with dramatic and seemingly deadly attacks is typically very forgiving and does not result in much damage. All guns have an automated lock on feature, there is no need to aim and so forth.Personally, I did not mind this. I enjoyed the relaxing and childish nature of the game. This stress free approach also ensured I was never frustrated, stressed or bored.  Those looking for a challenging coop game, this is not it. What it lacks in challenge, it more than makes up for with its engaging story and one-of-a-kind masterful coop gameplay.It Takes Two features a unique "Friend's Pass" system which allows anyone to download the full game. If both players do not own the full game, the first chapter can still be played at no cost to either party. If one person owns a copy of the full game and invites a friend who has downloaded the friend's pass, it is all free for the coop partner. There is no need for 2 people to purchase the game. Not only does this feature vitally increase accessibility, but it is also a fantastic and magnanimous move by developers, one I very much appreciate. For those interested in lag and connectivity issues, I played this online from Australia, with my coop partner being in the UK. Despite being at opposing regions of the globe, gameplay remained explicitly smooth. Perhaps the only fault could be the rare delay in cutscenes, but actual gameplay was unaffected.Majority of the game is experienced in typical split screen fashion; however, the camera angles are constantly changing, sometimes through a top down view or a shared screen for cutscenes. Each chapter is visually stunning, vibrant and immensely detailed. It maintains the child-like themes and brings household items to life, giving personalities to kitchen items, plants, tools and more. The metaphoric representation is hilarious, obvious and relatable. Ranging from exploring a winter wonderland (inside a snowglobe), the deep sea or infiltrating the wasps inner lair, each area provides a different and visually appealing aesthetic.   The voice acting is exceptionally well done, delivered with emphatic emotion and allows players to better relate to the characters relationship woes and concerns. The entire soundtrack is exhilarating, particularly during boss battles and just like the rest of the game, is ever-changing.There are not enough words to adequately explain the experience of It Takes Two. Featuring extremely varied and diverse gameplay, it stands out among other coop games as a true masterpiece. Its high-quality production proves that the once hated split screen still has a place in modern gaming. I highly recommend this to anyone looking for an unforgettable coop experience. For 12-15+ hours of playtime and a pricetag of $AU49.95, it is well worth it and deserves the many accolades it has already received.This review copy was provided to the Devils in the Detail curator.

author: ♡LlamaLoops♡
review: Absolutely breathtaking! I played this game with my fiance. We got about 14 hours of game play in to beat the entire game BUT there are definitely things we didn't go all the way through with (like all the mini-games). The music, the art, the character design, game mechanics, and settings were all gorgeously done. We had SO much fun in this game. With each level comes new items to use and new evasive maneuvers to participate in. Each character you meet is so unique and moves the story along in an exciting way. This game is definitely worth the $40. We aren't sure what next game we will play together after moving from this one because this one made such a positive impression on us. Definitely recommend!

The cutscenes flow very well from the gameplay, creating a seamless narrative that the players feel engaged in. Humor A+Soundtrack A+Ease of Multiplayer Experience A+Learning Curve A+We are roughly 1/5th of the way through the game, according to minigame unlocks, and we are so excited to keep going. TL;DR: Grab a friend and get ready to laugh, because It Takes Two is setting up for an early GOTY win.

author: Mark Y.
review: With approximately 55,000 reviews -- 96% of them positive -- at the time of my posting this, it is hard to know what more I can add to 's well-deserved acclaim.  As others have said, it is an excellent cooperative multiplayer game with very satisfying controls, varied levels, and superb production values in art and audio.Aside from these things, what stood out to me was the game's decency.  It is *anti*-exploitative, quite deliberately excluding features like collectibles (let alone microtransactions) or character advancement that are predicated on Skinner box treatment of the player.  Rather than finding ways to  more from the player (money, time, etc.), the developers have found ways to  more to the player, with many small delights to be found.  In addition to not exploiting the player, the game doesn't exploit its characters -- only very occasionally playing the cheap tropes that the game's set-up would tend to invite.  The game's narrative may lack subtlety and surprise, but its straightforward positive message never feels preachy, perhaps because the scenario is so ridiculous.It is rare to play a big-budget game (the credits go on FOREVER!) that seems to have as its goal that players will find a fun, full, satisfying experience and go away better than they came.

author: KotalKen
review: First off, I'm not the type of person that is into story mode games nor am I someone who writes reviews, I tend to get bored of them really quick. I'm more into multiplayer pvp type of games. With that being said, this is one of the games I actually completed. Here is the general review checklist and then my review right after.---{Graphics}---☐ You forget what reality is☑ Beautiful☐ Good☐ Decent☐ Bad☐ Don‘t look too long at it☐ Paint.exe---{Gameplay}---☑ Very good☐ Good☐ It‘s just gameplay☐ Mehh☐ Starring at walls is better☐ Just don‘t---{Audio}---☐ Eargasm☑ Very good☐ Good☐ Not too bad☐ Bad☐ Earrape---{Audience}---☑ Kids☑ Teens☑ Adults☑ Human☑ Lizards---{PC Requirements}---☐ Check if you can run paint☑ Potato☑ Decent☐ Fast☐ Rich boiiiiii☐ Ask NASA if they have a spare computer---{Difficulity}---☐ Just press ‚A‘☐ Easy☑ Significant brain usage☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master☐ Difficult☐ Dark Souls---{Grind}---☑ Nothing to grind☐ Only if u care about leaderboards/ranks☐ Isnt necessary to progress☐ Average grind level☐ Too much grind☐ You‘ll need a second live for grinding---{Story}---☐ Story?☐ Text or Audio floating around☐ Average☐ Good☑ Lovely☐ It‘ll replace your life---{Game Time}---☐ Long enough for a cup of coffee☐ Short☐ Average☑ Long☐ To infinity and beyond---{Price}---☐ It’s free!☑ Worth the price☐ If u have some spare money left☐ Not recommended☐ You could also just burn your money---{Bugs}---☑ Never heard of☐ Minor bugs☐ Can get annoying☐ ARK: Survival Evolved☐ The game itself is a big terrarium for bugsThe game itself is phenomenal. The developers definitely knew what they were doing. An attention grabber right from the start. This adventure is well done from the beautiful scenery to the unique boss battles. There are so many different puzzles and every level requires different types of thinking. Nothing ever repeats itself. There are also mini games to add some level of competition so its not always about working together. There is a roller coaster of emotions and the game itself is definitely worth the price. Especially since one friend can play the game for free with the game pass. I will however need therapy after one scene with the elephant doll. Other than that, 9/10.

author: Wandering Cavalry
review: It Takes Two definitely deserves all the awards it has. This is probably the best representative work of the ninth art of the game: game content that can be enjoyed by any age, shocking camera movement and animation, rich and detailed scene design, fine modeling, wonderful music, and philosophical content of the story, and most importantly as a game, it has very creative gameplay and top-level design.It is generally believed that there is a close connection between this work and A way out. The two games have many similarities in gameplay, but in this one, you can see a leap in game quality. This game is undoubtedly suitable for people of any age, even if they are not very interested in games, they could enjoy it a lot.This game is simply too good. But in my opinion, the only shortcoming is that the plot is not too impressive-and this may also be a compromise for all ages. The most impressive thing about this game is the ability that coordinate between characters on different levels. I never felt bored and tired throughout the game, and I was always shocked by the creator's creative ideas. And since the game director is also a movie screenwriter, you can enjoy a visual feast that is no less than a Hollywood movie experience.No matter what kind of gamer you are, this game is definitely worth a try, and it will not let you down. If there are a few shortcomings of this game, apart from the fact that the plot is difficult to impress the players deeply, I am afraid that you must need a friend to play -after all, you can't play a co-op game alone, isn't it?

author: Tamaster
review: (ITT) is an experimental co-op only game set in the present times. The story is about May and Cody, a couple that has seen their relationship progressively deteriorate over time, bringing them close to divorce. This triggers deep suffering in their only daughter - so much in fact, that it awakens an unknown magical force, that transfers her parents' consciousnesses into two animated dolls. The two will have to work together in order to regain their real bodies - and maybe, find love again along the path.ITT manages to deliver a fairytale-inspired general setting, that branches off with diverse locations, ranging from lush forests to castle dungeons and intricate clockworks. The level of detail and care in their realization is impressive, as in some cases, entire miniature cities ripe with details, minigames (and even NPCs!) were created just for boosting immersion. Textures, effects, animations and everything else are of the highest caliber, up to par with 2021 AAA release levels.There is no other game in my knowledge, that mashed together so many genres in a row, and successfully at that. Mainly, this title focuses on puzzles and platforming which are seen a lot during the adventure - however, each stage has several unique segments that transport players into an entirely new gameplay style: Action RPG, Shooter, Fighting, Boss Fights and much more. Such an astounding bouquet, keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting at all times.That's right! In a time plagued with DLCs, micro-transactions, live service games and whatever other hogwash, it's refreshing to see a developer committed to give players value for their money. Anyone who purchases the game, will be able to invite any of their friends to play along the whole adventure, for free. This can be used on multiple people even, if needed, not just once.The acting of the two main characters is spot-on, as it feels emotional and involving at all times. Secondary characters as well sit on a solid level: there is definitely good quality work in this aspect, across the board. Music and effects that encompass each stage feel appropriate, manage to emphasize the action or scene at hand in the right ways, most of the time. Even if ITT's narrative takes major inspiration from fairy-tales, and has a goofy, humorous tone most of the time, it doesn't shy away from some segments that are instead very unsettling. For instance, there will be a part where the protagonists will proceed to . These parts are all the more impressive, because of their stark contrast with the general theme.The choice of separating the view-area in two would be understandable, for local matches on the same computer - however it proves bizarre for online ones on two separate machines. Even if it is helpful to look in the other player's screen (sometimes), that's never a mandatory mechanic, so ultimately ITT could do without the screen-splitting. Especially on smaller monitors like the ones of laptops, the size reduction certainly could prove uncomfortable.My usual Gameplay Breakdown cannot be applied to It Takes Two, as it mixes-and-matches so many genres, making a full breakdown of each would prove nigh impossible, other than a spoiler as well., ITT puts high emphasis on Platformer and Puzzle Game: in each stage, there will be multiple obstacle courses that often will need the combination of the two players' different tools or powers, in order to overcome them. The difficulty curve of such enigmas and platforming sections gently soars, first to accustom players to the new mechanics, and then leaving them free to use them at their full potential. However do not expect a hardcore challenge, as the game is more oriented towards an average / casual audience - which is fine, as it's not *too* easy, anyway. vary for each level, and in many cases they are unique, non-repeating sections with their own, specific gameplay mechanics. For instance, one of them will have players being able to manipulate their body size and gravity respectively, while another one will see Cody pilot an aircraft while May mans the turret to fend off attackers. Multiply cases like this for the totality of the game's duration, and the result is amazing variety. are found throughout the adventure, and put Cody and May against each other in small, competitive-oriented challenges. Also in this case, each minigame is unique and original, can be replayed unlimited times, and some of them will even change or become more difficult as the rounds go on. Winning or losing them doesn't give anything to the victor, they're just for fun's sake, a diversion. Certain side activities though, have unique achievements related to them.Sure, players can die during a boss fight, a platforming section, or any of the unique combat-oriented ones - although a game over only triggers when both are dead at the same time: the blessing of immortality allows both to quickly resurrect if defeated. Checkpoints are anyway very frequent and forgiving, even boss fights will checkpoint at every new phase's start, so losing progress in a frustrating way is not an issue.

author: Fedoteh
review: I was born in '91, and started playing videogames with the Sega Genesis when I was 5 or 6. Ever since, I played hundreds... thousands of games. This game is something else. It's majestic game design. Seriously, no one has ever done a better coop game than this one. The way the story unfolds, the characters, the topics they discuss. Even the message the game sent! It's incredibly well written.And the most important thing: Game mechanics. The game introduces scenarios and mechanics that quickly get discarded before it turns repetitive. Every new segment of the game is worthy of wonder, both by its visual but also by surprise: they always make you do something different, unique. Something that the game will never let you do again. It's like playing 15 different games under the same premise.The only aspect you have to consider is that this game is better for couples. Playing it with a friend is fun, but you'll be missing a lot of references to the relationship with your couple.Do yourself a favor and play this game as soon as you can.

author: PK
review: It's been a long time since I've played a game like It Takes Two. Very few games are able to truly understand the meaning of a cooperative experience. A lot of games tout "co-op" as a major feature of the game, but it never expands past the fact that you can play the game with your friends. Games like It Takes Two and Portal 2 aren't like that. This game is not functional without a friend and it takes full advantage of that fact. I highly recommend picking this game up especially since your friend can hitch a ride with you for free with the Friend's Pass or Steam Remote Play.Gameplay has always been the biggest selling point of any video game and It Takes Two does not disappoint. It's a cooperative puzzle platformer at its core, but don't let that brief description fool you. It Takes Two is constantly throwing gameplay elements from every possible genre to keep things fresh for the whole experience. One moment you're playing a third person shooter with an extremely deadly combo attack and the next moment you're playing a top-down RPG with magic spells. Every chapter of the game gives you a new toy to play with and each mechanic is flushed out to its fullest potential. There was one moment when I thought an area's gimmick was fairly boring with the magnets, but then shortly after I was given a turret that fired magnets that were used to traverse a massive wall. The sheer amount of genres displayed here makes It Takes Two look like a love letter to video games as a whole. And that's not even mentioning the fact that each player gets a different toy to play with. The only exception is the magnet level, but every chapter gives both Cody and May a different tool and mechanic to play around with. Let's use the shooter chapter I mentioned earlier as an example: Cody gets a goop gun that stuns enemies and May gets a flare gun that ignites bugs. And that's where the beautiful cooperative elements come into play, combining those two guns together creates a massive explosion that instantly kills most enemies. It Takes Two's fearlessness when it comes to new mechanics and the fact that the two playable characters offer different experiences makes it so this game has amazing replay value. Movement is another thing the game loves to play around with. There are tons of different vehicles for you to operate in drastically different methods. And that's not to say the game is weak without these mechanics, the core platforming and puzzle solving are strong in their own right. Every puzzle felt very natural and my friend and I never once had to look up a guide when we got stumped. Overall, the game design showcased here is an absolute marvel.Something I wasn't expecting to praise this game for is the artwork and environmental design. While the normal human models are kind of uncanny to look at to me, I think the toy models you actually play as and everything else look really nice! All of the artwork is fairly pretty and what I believe should be the standard for modern AAA games. There's a lot of attention to texture and detail for every model in the game and I really appreciate that. I swear it's good but it's hard to write "This fur looks like actual real-life fur" for too long. What I was really taken aback by was the amount of unique environments that were explored. I was worried that the game was going to entirely take place inside the house and everything was just going to be navigating furniture. That fear was quickly shot away as soon as I started exploring the inside of a tree-cave-like-system and inevitably found my way to a medieval castle. One of my personal favorite environments was the use of a snowy wasteland village that entirely took place inside of a snow-globe. It's a treat that the environments are as varied as the game design. And for a platformer, it's pretty important that the environment you navigate is interesting to look around for where you need to go to next. Oh and a quick note: I recommend turning off the soundtrack and listening to your own music of choice. The soundtrack isn't all that engaging and it's very cliche at some moments.However, my biggest complaint for It Takes Two has to be the game's story and writing. The plot is simple, Cody and May are getting a divorce and The Book of Love is a magical entity trying to get them to fall back in love. A love story would sort of imply that the main characters would have some actual chemistry, but I didn't believe Cody and May liked each other (even as just friends) for a single moment. It was very weird for them to be constantly at each other's throats and blaming each other for every little thing only for them to get back together seemingly out of nowhere in the final chapter. There was no build-up to that moment. There wasn't a slow second spark of love, they just went a complete 180 on their opinion of each other in the span of a few minutes. There was even a moment where my friend and I mocked Cody for complaining that May isn't at home because she's paying the bills. Cody and May in general aren't very interesting characters anyways, as they boil down to the stay-at-home mom and stay-at-work dad tropes with the genders swapped. Dr. Hakim was also an extremely annoying character that the game wanted me to like, but he only filled the role of an irritating antagonist up until the final chapter. Tone is something I think It Takes Two struggles with. It's a divorce story with profane language, but with such a childish attitude and understanding of the whole situation, so much so that it got to the point that it was actually humorous. There was a major plot point where the couple decided the best course of action was to make their daughter cry and that was eventually followed with one of the darkest scenes I've seen recently. If you've played the game, you know what I'm talking about and it was completely out of nowhere to me. Both my friend and I didn't care for the story at all and we actively wished for a different outcome in regards to the ending. It's really hard to care about a love story when both of the main characters are insufferable and hate each other.Overall, It Takes Two is worth the $40 price point. It was really surprising to see EA publish a genuinely good game, although that's most likely because they had little involvement in the creative process. It Takes Two is a wonderful experience that I enjoyed from start to finish. There wasn't a single dull moment in the 12 hour playtime.

author: Eraserhead Baby
review: I never write real reviews for games but this honestly the first time I ever really felt compelled to write something that had such an impact on how I view the medium of Cooperative games.When I first heard of the game I was shocked to realize it was from Josef Fares (A Way Out, The Game Awards “♥♥♥♥ The Oscars” guy (legend).) I had known him firstly from when Jerma985 played A Way Out on stream with a friend and thought of the concept of how Josef tackled Co-op games was interesting; something that was in real need of innovation because it always just feels like an afterthought with most games. While the way it was tackled was interesting, I thought the gameplay itself was more or less lacking in comparison to the story and ideas that they kept serving up to the two playing. Finally It Takes Two was announced and honestly at first I thought it looked corny and such a weird departure from the more serious tone Josef’s game had in the past. I was cautiously optimistic regardless of my really baseless first impression because as we know from Josef, passion and determination run through that man’s blood like water runs through a river. After waiting for a while since launch and somewhat keeping an eye on the game, I was shocked to see the sheer amount of positive reviews for the game (and the bad takes from negative reviews from people who played like, 1 hour of the game that took me nearly 15 to finish.) I decided to take a chance on the game, to get myself out of the rut of playing my usual 3-4 games I do. I bought a copy for my best friend and I for their birthday after casually mentioning it here and there. I wasn’t too pleased with Origin integration (side note, ♥♥♥♥ game launchers, stop making us launch from 2 separate things!) but I knew it was just a necessary minor inconvenience in order to play.Let me tell you, the reviews do not lie about how fantastic this game is. From the first moments you can move around you feel how fluid the 3D platforming is, coupled with the beautiful graphics and genuinely fun gameplay. I was actually impressed from the first level of the game. It was such a simple idea turned into this adorable, fun and quirky adventure between this couple trying to fix their broken relationship. The various game elements that shift every chapter to add constant variety without feeling overwhelming having to adapt to how you face new challenges. Level design is so creative and fun that every new area just kept me filled with awe as I constantly wondered how they could possibly top the previous area. I could talk more about the story, gameplay, levels, concepts all day but I would be afraid of spoiler territory for folks who are questioning whether or not to get this. It’s hard for me to remember the last time I had my face light up in surprise or like, genuine fun over experiencing a game. The memories you have with the person you play with could go on and on. There are many games that influence this, because in art we’re always informed by the things we’re inspired by; but few actually are able to mold the medium to create something so compelling and fun. It was an experience from front to back that was so much fun and I’m happy I got to experience it with someone.

author: Kaiser-Fahim
review: This game was so breathtakingly amazing that I am genuinely sad that it is over.My 6yo daughter and I loved every moment and not only did the chracters grow to love each other again, but I watched my daughter grow over the last few months from trying her best to play it with me, to absolutely blindsiding me with how many of the puzzles and platfroming she now pulls off effortlessly.When it ended it was So so so bitter sweet. It had been our thing to do when we had time together lately and now we have no idea what will fill that void of relaxing gaming with my little girl. She rushed to tell my wife we had finished it and she was so proud! But then when she returned to the study, she asked me if I could find a game just like this one...but one does not exist!I have never had a game in the last 25 years or so effect my heart so much as this game, it remind me of when I was young, discovering Shining Force 2 for the first time!The game play, the MASSIVE amount of genres touched on, the secrets, the easter eggs, THE MINIGAMES! The story, amazing!I have never played anything like this. As the final cut scene played my daughter said, "you know daddy, mummy would probably be crying at this bit", with tears in my eyes I turned to my daughter and said with a smile, "Yeh, she might, but not me hey, Id never cry" It was at this point she noticed my tears, she smiled and gave me a big hug. Now tell me what game could achieve that.10/10 a fan for life. Absolutely speechless on how good this game is!

author: Colonel Patrick Sanders
review: I remember I played the previous game from Hazelight Studios “A way out” a couple of years ago with a friend, and we absolutely loved the concept. A game focused around co-op with a good story, where you need to help each other out to get further all while being able to see each other's screen. So naturally we got hyped as soon we heard about It Takes Two.So ever since the trailer I’ve been keeping an eye on this game, and recently me and a friend finally had some time to start it. From the beginning we were instantly blown away. You follow the story of Cody and May. They get shrunk down and need to find a way to get back to their normal human size. As you get shrunk down, everyday stuff like a book, a closet or a bed suddenly become huge, and this is where for me personally the magic lies in the story/environments of It Takes Two.Gameplay feels great. Movement is really well done, interaction with objects is good and during the game you get a wide variety of weapons and abilities. The game mixes combat, platforming, racing and much more really well. And not only mechanics change, perspective also changes. From third person, to 2D, to top-down. Everything is blended together perfectly. Never once during the game I felt like mechanics became boring.The story of It Takes Two is also really well done. It’s interesting, entertaining, has humor and the further you get, the more you start to actually live with the characters, and understand them.Environments are definitely the strength of It Takes Two. As I said above you walk around in everyday scenarios such as a garden, a bedroom, a childrens playroom etc. The twist is, because you’re so small all these environments get a complete other dynamic. Suddenly you’re spending tens of minutes just to climb a bed, that small garden with plants becomes its own world where squirrels are bigger than you, you become friends with spiders and that small pond becomes a real challenge to cross. Not only are environments interesting, original and well thought through, they’re also filled with easter eggs, minigames and fun little interactions. I highly recommend taking a minute and exploring every corner of a map. You’ll find so many small interactions and details that make you smile. This has to be one of the most detailed games I’ve ever played.Ambiance wise this game is amazing. It has beautiful graphics, environments are jam packed with details and music/sound effects are excellent. From the main music, to character voices to small details like walking over a piano and actually hearing each key have its own tone. Props to the developers for the amount of detail.For me, It Takes Two is one of the best, if not the best game I’ve played in the last few years. I enjoyed every bit of it and played from beginning till the end with a big smile on my face. I encountered only 1 bug(visual one) and the game is actually quite long for the amount of content you have. It took me and my friend 15 hours. I recommend everyone who likes co-op games to buy this. Especially because whether you play local or online, only 1 person needs to buy this. The other person can either join through local play or the free friend pass. This is a game I will remember for a lifetime.

author: Grubby Shinoda
review: is definitely the best co-op games I’ve ever played! It has had to be the game of the year to me so far. It is really amazing and breathtaking.There are few such excellent two-player co-screen games on the market. I’ve played  which is also published by EA before and it is a great co-op game too with a refreshing gameplay and a dramatic story. Until this year,  refreshes players’ perception once again. It has richer interactive content and much greater gameplay.The two protagonists, May and Cody, are a couple with a rift in their relationship. When the couple was about to divorce, their daughter wished that their parents would not be separated, which triggered the power of application to allow the souls of their parents to be attached to a pair of dolls that are made of wood and clay. Shocked, they could only temporarily form a wartime alliance in order to recover their bodies, and stumbled into a big adventure.With bright colors and cute character modeling, the overall plot tone of the game is relaxed and cheerful. However, part of the plot in the game also exposes the utilitarianism and selfishness in the adult world. For example, the first BOSS vacuum cleaner lost its sanity under the promise that the husband and wife would repair it again and again, and turned into a monster. Finally, the eye-catching violent execution method is just like the 18 prohibition inserted in a children’s picture book which makes the scalp numb.The difficulty design of the game is generally relatively friendly, and the condition for failure is that both characters must fall into a state of disability. When one player is in a state of being unable to move, click the button continuously to fill the "heart" in the center of the screen and it will appear on the battlefield again. Even if both of the players fail, don’t’ worry too much. The game has many save points and will not bring severe punishments that will require a long run from the start once you fail.The settings of each level are just right. From the beginning to the end, all the content will not be told to you in a moment. Basically, it guides us step by step, and when we reach the right opportunity, we begin to freely explore the pattern we are looking for. We will gradually learn a lesson from exploration and adventures.Each level will have different gameplay and different props. Basically, it needs two people to coordinate at the same time to use it. Players can also use their own props to spoof each other, which is really interesting.The decryption aspect is also considered part of this game. The overall difficulty is not very difficult. It can be researched with a little thought. Every location needs time to explore and research to get through.The game itself also has a lot of challenges and a certain degree of difficulty, which adds more fun to this game. There are many different mini-games in different levels. If two people find the mini-game, they will start the game. Of course most of the games require a pair of fast hands.There will be a boss battle in every level, and every boss’s style of play is painstakingly designed. I personally think that the battle is more repetitive, but in fact it is not very boring. Many of them require two coordinated operations. The overall difficulty is not very high, but it also tests the game operation ability of two players.I hope there will be more similar games on the market.

author: Vigilante01X
review: I would never ever imagine that my first review of a game will be an EA's game.I would never ever imagine that I, a lone singleplayer nerd gamer, would ever play a coop style game with a true friend.I would never ever imagine that I would be sobbing after the old-fashion everyone-can-guess ending.Despite all the breaking-up and homie-in-love jokes on the reviews, I wasn't expecting the influences of this game brought into real lives.I somehow grew a strong crush on my coop friend during playing this beautiful shiny game. Because obviously every single set in the game is a romantic scene where you want stay forever. You never get bored as long as the story's moving and you never feel lonely cuz there's always someone watching your back or someone you need to attentively take care of. My partner and I live 6000 miles away from each other and have an upside-down time difference, we're like an international team. So in real life we most likely won't be able to have any intersections. But it just doesn't matter cuz in the game, I can throw my butt at her face anytime she makes a noob move and murders me. My partner is not even an English speaker, so if someday she happens to see this review, my ridiculous crush on her probably have already faded away, but the beautiful and lovely memory of this incredible journey won't.

author: Skitz
review: This game pushes a positive message that I don't think I've seen before in a video game: - "Marriages will have problems"- "It may feel like there are no resolutions, but it IS possible to salvage the marriage"- "It's not just about you, think about the effects divorce has on the young children" (my favourite one)It makes for some surprisingly unique and shockingly dark gameplay. We couldn't believe some of the things we saw (Cutie). The absolute horror, dear gawd....we will never forget lol. I haven't played a co-op game this clever since "A Way Out". The mechanics stay fresh as they keep changing, and they are implemented in really fun and imaginative ways. Ways I've never seen before. Sometimes we stopped moving forward just to have fun goofing around and enjoying whatever mechanic was being implemented at the time. There are mini games littered throughout that are all a blast to play (at least once), and they let you take a break from working together for some friendly competition/feud building.The controls are responsive, and the graphics are pretty damn good especially if you have the hardware for it. We had a lot of laughs with the characters and the writing, and the voice acting was spot on. Everything feels top notch. I do have small gripes though. First is with the audio. It's happened probably 3 or 4 times during our 16hr playthrough. Sometimes the audio would go out and never return, or go out and return when the sequence changed, then go out again when the sequence changed again. The only fix for this was a hard restart. We've also had UE4 crashes, and even a game breaking bug that we fixed by restarting and doing the sequence over like 3 times. While most of the experience was smooth, it DID happen enough to start slightly getting under our skin at certain points.As a package though I'd still recommend this game to couples or people in long term relationships. It's a great co-op game period, but I think couples will definitely get the most out of it. If your relationship is currently on the rocks due to games like Overcooked, this game will have you sailing off into the sunset again. Best to wait for a sale though as there are indeed a few bugs, and your mileage may vary.

author: Menphues (Kyle)
review: What a fantastic heart warming game! Also, allowing a free friend pass to play with a friend, amazing!I loved A Way Out and I love this. Really, this game has raised the bar and as long as they keep making them, people like myself who love these will keep buying them, really it is a work of art to play and experience a well written story!Graphics: The graphics of the game are pretty unique and visually gorgeous to look at, really. There are some great effects that really set the bar to something awesome. There are lots of little detailing in the game that makes it amazing from sparks to glowing effects etc etcAudio: The audio of the game from the voice acting to the sound effects, it's all spot on really good to listen too, the audio alone is a masterpiece.Controls: Super easy to pickup, change your keys and get used too with very easy character control.Gameplay and everything else: The game is a 2 player co-op puzzle solving master peice. Each level is completely different from the last and it builds upon a story of a young girl who's parent are divorcing and her tears basically turn you into the puppets, there is where I will leave it with no spoilers, but you go through basically trying to rebuild your relationship with a Mexican book of love, why is he Mexican? I do not know but it's amusing.The puzzles in the game are unique and all over the place, each map, zone and area changes to completely new every time so when you are going through, you do not get the feeling it's rinse and repeat, it's all different style of puzzles every part of the map, plus you get some mini-games along the way to find and compete against your friend, which makes the game enjoyable.Overall, the story, art style, sound, gameplay is just amazing and one hell of a great purchase for anyone looking to play something different.You can be zipping along a zip line to running for your life to solving a puzzle to defeating a boss, to sucking the eyes out of a hoover... I laughed so much because it was dark but appealing to my humour to beating a monkey boss with a gun, FUN.Would I recommend the game? 100% Yes, the game is worth full price and discounting this game is an insult because it's just superb and deserves the positive scoring it's got all over the place.My only issue is in the trailer you can see the top down spell and warrior scene, I would love that as a full style Diablo game, which would be awesome!

author: Ungraceful
review: Best co-op game that I have ever played, only comparable to Portal 2, but I think this one is even better. Each level has a different core mechanic and each of those is really well thought out and polished and works perfectly in a co-op setting. On top of that, the story is really well paced and executed. Plenty of funny moments, plenty of touching moments. The characters are also superb. This game might be the closest thing to a perfect game I've played.

author: Ash
review: As someone who as play a LOT of games over the years I suffered from a lot of burnout recently for months. There was no game that I could play that made me enjoy video games anymore. I thought my time with games had come to an end....until I found this game. This masterpiece is a 11/10. The amount of work and art put into this game is just beautiful. I have enjoyed every single second of this game as well as the little things they put into this. I honestly would recommend this to anyone to at least try the demo. Yeah it goes through origin but that does not matter in the end for this artistic masterpiece of a game. These are the types of games we need, and this is the game that made me have hope for games in the future.

author: Lametta
review: Usually i dislike EA for destroying my beloved childhood franchises and developing games to just make money.Seems like the exceptions prove the rule.I didnt buy any EA games for a long long time but now im happy i did.The dev who made this game put a lot of love into it. Its almost like a playable Disney animation movie (with lots of gameplay and alot of varied mechanics).Pros*Great Artstyle*Very Charming*Likeable Characters*Good Story (like a disney animation movie)*Great and Varied Gameplay ( there are different game mechanics all the time)*Good ControlsCons*Might be awkward to play this with a bro ?!? since its about the relationship of  a coupleAll in all if you have a wife/gf that you want to get into gaming or that is already gaming you should buy this 100%.Hoping for a second game.

author: HEKAU
review: is no stranger to cooperation-focused games and the mechanics they're married to, first with 2013's  (which is where I started with them, becoming a fan of their work since) then 2018's , but It Takes Two takes it to another level with this title. Its gameplay is 100% dependent on each other as both players need to rely on one another to accomplish tasks and complete levels (each player has to be fairly competent since one can't carry the other throughout the entire game), a lesson that both protagonists need to learn in the game's narrative. I found the abrasive engineer wife x whiney nature-lover husband dynamic unrealistic, which I feel is the biggest flaw with this game, but they're both annoying [together] and no doubt serve to drive the point home about their marital conflict and toxicity within their coupling. Dr. Hakim also gets pretty grating as the over-the-top talking book but at least his heart's in the right place. The daughter character, who sets this whole adventure in motion, is probably the most sympathetic character of the lot and maybe even the most relatable for many. Gameplay wise there's a plethora of diverse mechanics and genre styles including both 2D and 3D platforming, race and escape sections, third-person shooting, and lots of puzzles. You'll never get bored or tired because there's so much variety and no section ever overstays its welcome. This is one of those games that'll have you smiling from ear-to-ear and get you right in your nostalgia feels. Take a pass on the couples therapy and buy this for a one-time fee of $40 (or less), it'll save you tons of psychiatry bills in the long-run...and if you can't complete this game together, then you might be better off apart.   Xbox Gamepad

author: Metsakurat
review: It Takes Two is the best co-op game of the year and one of the best games of 2021.It's hard to describe It Takes Two. On the surface, it looks like a normal third-person platformer and that's what it is for the most part but it definitely isn't all the game is offering.The game has a great variety of sections. A great selection of sections you can select.There are chapters where the game plays like a third-person shooter. You and your friend each get a gun with unique abilities that you use to shoot down enemies and get through obstacles. There's also a lot of puzzle-solving, side-scrolling, fighting, racing, all kinds of platforming (they get really creative with platforming sections), and even a "Diablo-like" hack 'n' slash chapter where you and your friend play as a wizard and a knight. In this hack 'n' slash chapter you both have different abilities and the entire chapter is in an isometric view.There are also a bunch of mini-games to be found. In mini-games, you compete against each other in various challenges such as ice skating, target shooting, snowball fighting, etc.Mini-games are really fun and a great way to breathe from the oh-so chaotic and over-the-top fast-paced campaign.I say chaotic and fast-paced and the game is all that but it's also pretty casual and fun so don't be frightened by those scary words. It Takes Two is a great game for both "gaming veterans" and people who are new to gaming.From time to time you also end up in these big sandbox areas. You can explore around in those areas freely and exploring them is extremely rewarding and satisfying. You can stumble upon easter eggs, secret platforming sections, find previously mentioned mini-games and just discover both cute and funny stuff to interact with. 99% of the achievements are earned by exploring so be aware of that if you care about achievements. Completing the campaign gets you only one achievement out of 20!What about the story? Is it any good?The short answer to those questions is YES.The story is quite simple and pretty straightforward but it's also a pretty good story.It's funny, heartwarming, and even a bit traumatic at times. Poor Cutie - Those who know, know.You play as Cody and May. A married couple is about to divorce each other. You both go to take a nap after another one of your married couple's fights and you wake up as dolls.In order to get back to your real human bodies, you have to reignite the passion for each other, and to do that you have to work together. COLLABORATION is the keyword.The characters are well written, the humor is top-notch and never feels forced, and overall just great casual and family-friendly fun. It Takes Two is a breath of fresh air in terms of storytelling and combat alike.Definitely worth the full price not to mention only one person needs to buy the game and your friends can just download the free friend pass to play with you.There's also split-screen co-op which I used to play this gem of a game with my girlfriend and it was a truly pleasant experience. I know some people think your PC has to run two games at once when playing games in split-screen but that isn't true. Ran perfectly fine in 1440p, everything maxed out at 120fps.It's a great game to play with your friends but I'd say you definitely should play it with your girlfriend/boyfriend.

author: X3Na
review: An outstanding and awesome co-op game.+ story+ gameplay and mechanics+ each chapter with unique abilities/skills to help you through+ cool minigames to get competitve with + the enviornment and OST+ puzzles and dependency on each other to get things done+ Dr. Hakim the lewd love book and each boss was fun+ Local and online co-op (other person can use the friend pass version and play for free)~ certain split screen segments gave hiccups for few players but nothing bad.This game is worth playing and enjoying with your fav co-op partner, can be bf/gf or buddies or siblings or cousins.Best game played in 202111/10 would kill the elephant and mr.sucker(these 2 scenes were dark AF).

review: If the developers ever see this, thank you. This has been one of the best games I've ever played. It delivered a message I needed to hear for a long time. Well worth the money. From the bottom of my heart, thank you for this game.

author: Phunky
review: Played this with someone truly important to me, and while ironically we did not get through a full playthrough, it was a great game filled with mini-games, pure co-op gameplay, unique mechanics, and heart-warming moments. It is one of the few co-op games where each player has to rely on one other and their unique ability, which changes from level to level. The new mechanics that come into play are not a gimmick at all, are well thought out, easy to pick up, and coincide with the level-design. It's also peppered with a ton of competitive mini-games that are extremely fun. I think this game is the best co-op game I've ever played.Play this with someone you care about, you'll have a good time.

In this case, I played it with my eight-year-old son. We had fun and challenges the whole time; and we're nowhere near the end. author: Sebb:)
review: It Takes Two is a one-of-a-kind experience. There is a joy and whimsy to the entire game and so much variety it’ll keep players entertained and surprised from beginning to end. The world is so detailed and gorgeous and the cohesion between storytelling and gameplay is incredibly impressive. It’s the kind of game that proves there’s still plenty of room for innovation in games. A MUST PLAY FOR CO-OP Enthusiasts! 10/10 Would play again! I ain't crying YOU ARE

author: Snort Cannon
review: The absolute mad man that is Josef Farres is back with yet another pure co-op adventure.Story:The story of It Takes Two follows on two characters, Cody and May (you pick which one you want to play as in the opening minutes of the game). Their marriage is on the rocks and they are planning on getting a divorce. When your young daughter Rose hears of this, she runs off and begs for her parents to stay together and when she sheds her tears on two dolls, Cody and May consciousness are transported into the dolls. A book Rose owns named Dr. Hakim is your guide into exploring the crazy world around you while you try to save your marriage. The story of It Takes Two is absolutely delightful and is filled to the brim with plenty of magical moments and crazy set pieces that just create a one of a kind experience. The writing is top notch and the banter between the two leads is great and hilarious as they bicker constantly. There's plenty of laugh out loud moments as well and with how crazy the story gets at times, you will certainly going to crack up at the antics of the characters. Graphics:Graphically It Takes Two is a really brilliant looking game. You go through plenty of different environments and all of them feel incredibly alive to the point where taking some time off and exploring your surroundings just to take all of it in is just amazing. Going through winter wonderlands, toy sets, outer space and the wilderness is just amazing and some of the environments in the game are absolutely stunning.The design of Cody and May is also incredibly simplistic yet quite charming. They definitely look like something a kid would make out of spare parts and play with them, with some rough edges on them. Other NPC's you encounter through the game are also really unique and you visit plenty of environments through the game and their inhabitants differ in each location you visit to match the themes of the area, with tons of attention to detail. Audio:The audio design of It Takes Two is also incredibly top notch. The voice acting is incredible across the board and every single actor nails their characters. It's filled to the brim with charm and emotion that makes the experience that much more enjoyable when playing. The music is also incredibly charming, from relaxing tracks to awesome intense tracks during the more action packed moments of the game. Not to mention there's an entire chapter themed after music which has some of the best music in the game. Gameplay:Back when A Way Out came out, Josef Farres stated in interviews that the game would never have the same activity twice in a row, so in each level you would always do something new. I was shocked that this statement was true and It Takes Two takes that idea to an even new extreme. On the surface level It Takes Two is a 3D Platformer where you and your friend need to work together as a team to make it through the dangerous environments as you try to restore your marriage. You do plenty of jumping on platforms, however each level takes it up a notch and introduces a new gameplay element to keep things fresh from level to level. For example in one level the main two characters get two different tools with Cody getting a nail which he throw and make a platform for May to use, while May gets a hammer that allows you to destroy items and allows you to swing on the before mentioned nails. Once the level is done you get an entirely new set of mechanics like weapons, or super powers and that changes gameplay in major ways.Some of these moments are just purely amazing and you need to see them yourself to actually believe that yes that actually did just happen. Each chapter just gets increasingly more amazing and honestly that's where I will stop as not to spoil the amazing surprises this game has hidden for you to find.Now to break up the tedium of the story you can find plenty of other thing around the world like spots where you can interact with things like cameras, a painting canvas and a printer, etch a sketch and plenty of other things. One thing that was pretty popular in A Way Out was the competition mini games. Every so often Leo and Vincent will come across a friendly competition to take a break of them escaping from police. Cody and May also find these things scattered around the world. There's around 25 mini games you can find throughout the entire game and some of these are just tons of fun. One of these games me and my teammate found ourselves going back to even after finishing the game it was just that much fun and we had tons of fun competing against each other. However a few of these aren't that great, but that's like 2 mini games out of 25.Verdict:It Takes Two is pure and simple a borderline masterpiece. It's an amazing game that sparked so much joy and fun that most games wish they could do. If you have a friend or family member to tag along for the ride the experience is one of a kind and I have no trouble recommending it. Apart from minor technical hiccups like frame drops in certain areas, this game is pretty much perfect in my eyes and worth the money. Josef, wherever you take us next in your next crazy adventure, I will be there Day 1. Final Rating:10/10Pros:+ Incredibly charming and funny story+ Visuals are stunning+ Great audio design+ Each level is tons of fun and adds new mechanics to keep things fresh+ Mini games provide a nice palette cleanser+ Adding a pro just for that one easter eggCons:N/AIf you liked this review please consider following our groups and curator pages at  and

The levels, mechanics, world, humor, heartfelt and pure fun this game gives, makes me not care that it’s a casual baby game in terms of challenge that I slam other games for. Here it’s so non-gamers can take part in a once in a lifetime game that will be forever loved by all and sets a new bar for co-op design.

author: Pomelowe
review: Perfect game to play with a partner even if they're not that keen on video games. Working together is a must but there's also some optional mini-games to compete with each other. Really hoping for a sequel or more co-op adventures such as It Takes Two!

author: janner66
review: It Takes Two is a co-op split screen adventure for two people.Working closely together, you’ll need headsets to communicate verbally with each other to solve puzzles and co-ordinate actions.Ever evolving gameplay will have you visit almost every genre available in gaming, and although never difficult, it still somehow remains fresh, exciting and always entertaining.Cody and May are a married couple that are caught in a rut. They bicker and argue and have started to drift apart. Deciding enough is enough they agree to divorce.Their daughter Rose is upset that they are unhappy and feels a little neglected. To replace the love she is missing, she plays with a couple of dolls that she has made in her parent’s image. One day, after a particularly bad argument that she overhears, she confides in her dolls once again. A tear of sadness drops onto the dolls which magically transporting her parents’ life essence into them. Enter Dr Hakim, the book of love. He is tasked to remind Cody and May why they fell in love and sends them on a series of adventures reminiscing good times and rectifying the problems in their relationship.Cody and May must find a way back into their real bodies and maybe fix their relationship along the way.Its gameplay is incredibly varied and the story is wonderfully conceived. Presentation is top drawer with superbly drawn characters and environments, and flawless voice acting which is full of emotion. The main characters are incredibly likeable, especially Dr Hakim who is absolutely hilarious with his stereotypical Spanish flair and over exuberance. He will have you constantly laughing at his antics.Cody and May are portrayed quite sympathetically with their ongoing marital issues. The relationship problems are revealed in quite an adult fashion with an array of emotions acted surprisingly well. The game cleverly uses these relationship moments to drive the gameplay, and their trials and tribulations are played out in a wide variety of genres.The gameplay is so diverse. Almost every single genre of action gaming is covered, and it is all done well. The only criticism I would give is that sometimes platforming can be made more difficult by poor depth perception. There is not always a shadow to gauge character’s landings on jumps. If you die, it is not long before you are back in the game and starting roughly in the same place you died. This can sometimes behave erratically though. On a couple of occasions, I bypassed puzzles completely because I died and respawned next to my playing partner, circumventing my part of the puzzle.It's a great co-op experience. I think voice chat is essential however. It would be very difficult to play this effectively without verbal communication. The game is not easy but it certainly isn’t difficult either. I thought it was challenging in places but mostly you should be able to complete whatever the game throws at you without too much hassle. It Takes Two is designed to flow. It is constantly moving you along and it never feels frustrating. Its main objective is to make you have fun and that involves giving you a helpful hand whenever possible. You will die a lot, but respawns are generous and any progress gained is continued where you left off. The actual gameplay can be difficult and quite frantic but the inclusion of these benefits means you’ll complete tasks eventually and keep moving forward. This creates a cleverly paced game and manages to keep it fresh and varied throughout.Gameplay revolves around the story of Cody and May’s relationship.Dr Hakim, Book of love, is in charge and sets the couple tasks to try and rekindle their marriage and remind them why they fell in love.He introduces the level in a hilarious fashion. Typically, you have to make it to a certain point on the map by using your abilities and performing platforming elements. The special abilities are always changing depending on your environment. For example, Dr Hakim suggests that passion has been lost in your relationship. Cody used to love gardening so one level is set in your garden. The abilities revolve around the scene too, so Cody can control plants whilst May can water plants so that they grow for Cody to climb. You are constantly working together in true co-op fashion. Each level follows a different theme with new abilities to master. The abilities will always complement each other and ensure that you need to work as a team to complete your goals.Some abilities remain constant however. The couple can always run and perform double jumps and dashes. These are useful to navigate larger jumps and avoid enemies during boss fight scenes.The levels are incredibly well designed and integrate into the story perfectly. There are so many nice touches and small details that make all the difference. It’s fun just to go around the levels pressing buttons to see what they do or interact with objects. It usually results in something funny happening. It’s up to you how long you spend in each level though. The path is usually obvious so you can either mess around or just get on with it.The game should take between eleven and fifteen hours to complete depending on how much you interact with the levels. There are numerous achievements which will also add time but you’ll probably need a guide as they are not obvious to get.The game is so much fun that you could easily play it again and not get bored. The visuals are superb.Characters are very well drawn and feel incredibly life like.The environments are imaginative and cleverly designed around a theme. They look gorgeous and are very detailed.Voice acting is astounding. The characters emotional range is quite impressive, from moments of personal reflection to jokes and japes. It all sounds realistic and entertaining.Special effect noises are also amazing.

author: Stalwart87
review: For a game that won multiple awards I had high expectations and it exceeded it by a wide margin. I played this with my GF and the whole journey could be simply described as an emotional roller coaster but to only highlight its heartfelt story  would be to understate its well deserved acclaim. Imbued with the spirit of animated films during my childhood, it captured what it was that made those experiences magical. The fun gameplay can only be complemented by its brilliant level design which as a whole is a pallete for the senses. Whether it's the wacky thrills or moments of serene melancholy. Whatever it was, the game design intends to make the player feel certain emotions to outstanding effect. It's detailed in places where it doesn't have to be and the fact that the devs went the extra mile for a game of this genre, shows how much heart and soul was poured into this. It takes two is a tale of self realization and reconciliation. It's the stuff of what hopes and dreams are made of.

At no point did I go "Damn, this is kinda boring". The story kept me engaged, the comedy left me giggling and the beauty of it all left me speechless.9.5/10

author: jSM2704
review: If you even slightly like what you have seen and read about It Takes Two so far and are still contemplating whether or not you should buy and play it: DO IT. You won't regret your time with this Coop-Masterpiece, as long as you bring a good friend or don't mind playing with a randomly chosen Coop-Partner via the matchmaking system.The only real downsides are honestly the requirements for EA's Origin and an agreement to their EULA as well as a linked EA Account via Steam linking. But as long as you can live with that, there is no reason not to enjoy It Takes Two.

author: h8koN
review: Not yet finished the game, so my opinion is subject to change - although 7 hours in already, I doubt it - but I would like to applaud Hazelight for creating this absolute masterpiece. I got this game through EA Play to play with my girlfriend and both me and her are absolutely loving the experience so far. The mini-games are goofy and fun, the puzzles are good, relatively "easy" but not too easy either where you just zoom through everything, but not too hard either where you end up getting frustrated. When you die, you do not feel like you are punished either, which massively helps the game being an overall smooth and fun experience. As far as visuals go, the world is BEAUTIFUL and with a mind like mine that is capable of appreciating a very child-like enviroment, will leave you in awe at times. Visually this is a beautiful game, no ifs or buts. Also I applaud EA - not every day you hear someone say that - for having the friend's pass, where only one person needs to buy it in order to play it with a friend or loved one. This system is brilliant and should be present in more games. Without a doubt my favourite co-op game! Fantastic game that is worth the money whether you buy the whole thing or get it through an EA Play subscription. If you are looking for a game to play with a friend or better yet, a boyfriend/girlfriend/wife/husband, this is the one.

author: Prettycrap
review: Are you a millennial couple who grew up playing PS1, N64, PS2, Xbox, etc etc era 3d Platformers? You know like Spyro, Mario 64, Banjo-Kazooie, Crash Bandicoot, etc etc the list goes on. If you and your partner fall into this description this game is a must play. That's all there is to it. You will have a nostalgic time, but also earn like +20 relationship points in time spent having a blast together.Very impressed with how much this game is a game first and a story second. It has a story and characters, and they're good but I think I can tell all of the really big time money and effort has gone into the incredible imaginative level designs and worlds, the fun innovative two-person gameplay loops, and excellent gamefeel and control. It is also always mindful of the difficulty and somehow manages to repeatedly present sections and challenges that are both fun and engaging for people who play lots of videogames AND people who don't.This will be a benchmark co-op, home and family title that will be referenced for years, congratulations to all involved, and all who've had a delight playing it.

author: .:: fAERiEN ::.
review: It Takes Two is an exciting co-op action-adventure 3D platformer that is soooo much fun to play, especially while voice-chatting on Discord with someone you love and enjoy spending time with. The story is simple but meaningful. It's about working together to solve problems that arise, and it emphasizes the importance of dedicating both the time and the effort that are necessary in order to nurture and maintain a loving, strong and healthy relationship. When you really care about someone, it is entirely worth it and rewarding to do so, even though it's not always easy... because life, itself, is not always easy or predictable.  The main characters are a couple named May and Cody who are going through a divorce. Their daughter, Rose, is devastated by this and desperate to get them back together. She makes a wish on a book and her parents get transformed into small wooden dolls that she made to represent them. They are thrust into a magical world where they encounter The Book of Love AkA Dr. Hakim, the flamboyant, mustachioed deuteragonist with a Spanish accent who is determined to repair their relationship. They need to get through a series of challenges so they can return to their human form.  The world is colourful and absolutely gorgeous, the puzzles are perfectly balanced in terms of difficulty (not too easy but not too hard), the bosses are tough, the mini games are entertaining, and the dialogue sometimes makes me laugh because it's so cute and comical. Also, there's so much to explore and so many toys to play with that it often makes me feel like a little kid in the world's biggest playroom. Honestly? I can't recommend it enough. It has become one of my favourite gaming experiences in many ways, and I'm not at all surprised that it has won several awards.

I HIGHLY recommend it.BIG thanks to the developers for this fantastic game. <3 :)
