author: Emanuel
review: (It comes quite late in the game, so there is a lot of gameplay to be had before that, but do not play that with a child. It's very dark)  absolute best for playing co-op with a child. Puzzles are quite easy and short, and there are many game modes sprinkled throughout, making this an excellent introductory game for young gamers. Not to mention, small mini-games to unlock in each level. absolutely stunning! The world is colorful and detailed, most of it designed around a child's environment, with bosses who come to life in the same way a kid would imagine they would.So why the negative review?(No story spoilers, I'm just describing the event)Well, quite a long way into the game, the director decides to add a torture scene in which our protagonists have to catch and dismember a sentient toy, limb from limb, as it begs you to stop and play instead. Look, I get the trying to intentionally make the player uncomfortable and to question themselves and how far they are willing to go, I've played Spec Ops: The Line and it was one of the most unique gaming experiences I've ever had, but WHY on earth would any sane person have this in a colorful co-op game so perfectly designed for children? Why? What would this contrast achieve exactly?This feels like those stories on Facebook about people hiding razor blades in Halloween candy, but in game form.

author: LordGandhii
review: After playing  last year, it was very refreshing to play a pure co-op experience since there's not much of that on the market currently, and it left an itch that nothing's come close to scratching. So, I guess it's a good thing that Josef Fares and the talented folks at Hazelight decided to release another pure co-op game that expands upon the foundation laid by  called  And I'm happy to report that  is an incredibly entertaining experience that is a significant improvement over its prison break predecessor that surprised me in more ways than one.While I think most people are going to compare this game's visual style to something out of a Pixar film, I would say this game feels a lot closer to something like  It's a delight, with so much variety in the environments considering that the story is basically contained to one house. The game also did an excellent job of not being too overwhelming with color, which on top of being paired with great character designs (especially in regards to the playable characters), made everything visually distinct enough that you could tell who was supposed to interact with what without getting in the way of the style that the game was going for. While I did play this game with slightly messy settings because I was streaming it, I could tell that this game is an absolute looker in terms of its style and environments, so the game absolutely succeeded in this regard.As I said before,  expands on basically all of the concepts laid by its predecessor. While it is still largely a puzzle platformer, one of the game's biggest strengths is in its variety, as it would switch up the genre very frequently. The parts of the game where I was witnessing my partner take on a boss structured like Street Fighter, or where we were tearing through a castle using fire and ice powers like a Diablo game were my absolute favorite parts. They didn't overstay their welcome, and were always a great way to change the pace as soon as the platforming/puzzle segments started to feel dull. Both characters had ample opportunities to shine, and I didn't feel like the power-ups were skewed in favor of one character at any point. While the game's on the easier side, I still found it incredibly engaging and didn't mind the difficulty since the game was meant to be accessible to as many people as possible. The boss fights were also very fun, and never felt mindless to beat since they all had different mechanics that felt like a proper assessment of your skills with whatever tool you're using. In terms of a pure co-op experience, this is arguably as good as it gets. It's balanced, engaging, and a constant delight from start to finish. I have nothing to negative to say here.Where the gameplay was near perfect in execution, this game's biggest weakness is its story. The game tries to foreshadow a few things, (for example: ) but ultimately get disregarded as soon as they move on to the next setting. I also feel like the game was too lighthearted tonally, and should've leaned more into its Pixar-esque appearance by suddenly changing the tone to something heavier in order to drive home the game's themes and sticking to that tone for more than one scene. While I did like the characters, and the game was genuinely pretty funny, I thought they were the only redeeming qualities in a story that felt like an excuse to throw the players into different situations, when it had plenty of potential to expand upon its themes using player interaction. The story is funny and entertaining, but its unwillingess to take itself seriously makes it disappointingly shallow overall.Not much to talk about here. The voice acting wasn't particularly remarkable, and there were a handful of moments that took me out of the game, but it wasn't noticeably bad. The music is also serviceable, though I'd say it is of a higher quality than the voice acting overall, outside of the final song which I found rather underwhelming. The sound design also works well enough, though again I'd say it's nothing to write home about. Overall, it's fine, though it's nothing I'll be talking about years from now. In terms of value, I'd say it's worth it at full price just for the reason that  But even then, I'd still say it's worth it simply because you'll remember your time with it because of how it constantly finds ways to reinvent itself. Sure, the story isn't anything to write home about, but it's still very memorable just for how good the gameplay is. You're not going to play it more than once most likely, but it's definitely fun enough to warrant doing another playthrough with someone else if you wanted to. is an absolutely amazing co-op experience with a story that holds it back from being an all-time great. But even then, the story isn't going to significantly ruin your experience because the way the gameplay constantly finds ways to keep you engaged definitely makes up for this to a degree. If you have someone to play this with, it is absolutely worth your money just to help these types of short, story-driven co-op games become more commonplace. It's not the "perfect co-op game", but it comes quite close. I loved my time with this game and I cannot wait to see what Hazelight does next.  - 9.5/10 - 10/10 - 5.0/10 - 6.0/10 - 9.0/10+ Incredible gameplay variety+ Beautiful environments+ Humorous writing+ Well-paced+ Only needs to be purchased once to play with a friend- Shallow story and themes- Tonal issues

author: riv
review: Easily one of the best games I've played this year so far. Constantly creative and constantly improving on it's premise. Introduces a healthy flow of new content that improves on the content before it. Probably the best co-op experience you can have currently.

author: Nachy
review: Really fun! It Takes Two is the kind of game that does a lot of things, and for the most part, does it well. Coming from the same developers of the co-op-only game A Way Out, It Takes Two takes that familiar brand into a more gameplay-oriented experience.The game at its core is a 3D platformer and builds on top of that by throwing a variety of different gameplay concepts and scenarios built around the co-op experience.There's a lot of enjoyable platforming sections, and while going through them, you and your friend will be occupied as well with a different gimmick through each chapter of the game. Such gimmicks come in a mixture of different combat methods such as having one player cover enemies and obstacles with a flammable sap that the other player can detonate with their own unique fire projectile.During sections where it takes a focus on puzzles instead, you get different gimmicks such as the player navigating through an obstacle while another uses a device or ability to help the other player get through things. I found myself just enjoying spitballing ideas and figuring things out with my friends, and on the times we got stuck, it's less on the game being obtuse and just more on us just having moments of hilarious stupidity, which is its own kind of fun.Optional activities also are peppered throughout the game, with various competitive minigames and moments of exploration to serve as breathers between chapters. If you loved goofing off and playing minigames such as Connect Four in A Way Out, It Takes Two amplifies that idea further in this game.The game keeps this pacing mostly consistent throughout, and you'll never be doing the same thing twice. However, it does feel like the ideas start to falter towards the end, where the new gimmicks start just feeling like less interesting variations of what you were doing a few hours earlier. The game could have merged and cut out a few things to make the experience tighter and make the last hour less of a slog. Still, for the most part, there's hardly a dull moment throughout the game thanks to just the sheer variety it offers throughout the hours.Visually, the game looks fantastic. The environment variety alone is great, but the details put into them really show how much work is poured into the game. From experiencing daily household areas as miniature toys to beautiful snowy mountains, green gardens, and even really abstract spaces, it consistently manages to look really good.The narrative itself unfortunately isn't as compelling as A Way Out, and at best you might find the dialogue passable with a few chuckle-worthy moments, and at worst annoying. Nevertheless, the premise does serve its purpose as a vehicle for the scenarios you go through the game, and it does have a few notable moments, which I won't spoil, but I can say that it's both hilarious and horrifying and can guarantee that it will elicit a reaction.It isn't a deal-breaker but it would have been interesting to see if they minimized the plot further and just focused on the gameplay parts, as I feel like it is enough to carry the game, and taking out the story won't really impact the main enjoyment of the gameplay itself.I personally played this twice with two different friends, with the playthrough months apart to keep my experience somewhat fresh, and absolutely enjoyed both playthroughs and had fun rediscovering solutions to the game, alongside finding new stuff I didn't come across on my initial playthrough. It isn't the easiest game to do full replays with considering its long length, though the option for chapter selections and jumping through minigames instantly is a nice way to do bite-sized revisits.All in all, It Takes Two is a really enjoyable experience, and there is a lot of fun stuff to go through even on just a single playthrough. Like the neat thing with A Way Out, only one of you needs a copy to play the game together. If you're in the mood for a fun co-op experience, It Takes Two will provide a solid experience.

review: the main characters are bad people who do bad things for what they think are good reasons, but the majority of the game manages to be fun and generally light hearted, with engaging gameplay - until you get to the elephant, which is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up, and not at all in line with the tone of the rest of the game. all it does is make the player feel miserable, and drive home that the parents are selfish and don't care about their daughters well being in the slightest, just myopically focused on being "normal" again, regardless of the cost.

author: Wizard With No Mana
review: Never before had I played a game with such variety and flawless pacing. You end up spending just the right amount of time with each set of mechanics. You're never left with a feeling of wanting more, or a feeling of boredom.

author: Friends
review: I haven't had this much love for a game since I was a kid. You can really tell the devs love games, it has different types of gameplay every 5 minutes and both the graphics and the music are absolutely stunning. Best 40 euros I've spent in a very long time. 10/10

author: DoctorDoritos
review: 1st review on steam.This game is just beautiful, full of fun and I can tell it's full of great mechanics. Dr. Hakim looks pretty creepy to me tho, but I love it. PS. You only need one copy of the game, your friend can download the game pass for free.

author: Espadana
review: There is no doubt why this game won the "Game of the Year" award, I've played this game before with a friend on the EA Game Pass and decided to play it again, this time with my brother, both times I played it were super fun . This game is everything I wanted as a kid, to be a little creature walking around the house exploring and playing with my toys. It offers a very unique experience for you and those who play alongside you and it has a good replay value, i won't touch it for a while but there is no doubt i will play it in a few years.

author: Anyanka
review: The story was underwhelming. The gameplay was great, and the animation was fantastic. The level of attention to details was commendable. But for a game that had a heavy story for its selling point, the story fell short, rushed towards the end, and left the players with no resolve with its anticlimactic coda. It was but disappointing.That being said: RIP, Cutie III, queen of the Magic Castle. This world has been unkind to you.

author: Nod for Meow
review: One of the best games iv'e ever played! The Story, the gameplay, the mini games, and the ending was something else!! Seriously, buy it.

author: Shadi
review: Absolutely amazing game. Ever since Portal 2 I never thought we'd get another genuinely amazing coop game but I was proven wrong. Constantly new challenges, new abilities, and amazing design/characters/humour/story/graphics. 10/10

author: Sma.Guacamaya
review: AMAZING! I fall in love with this game from the beginning!!! It is a well told story from a family`s life. Maybe I cried a little already. Me and my lovely friend  are still not over the game, we still need to do much more. You can get 10 or 12 hours of fun guaranteed! And even if you completed the game, you can play it again and choose the other character. Because you will have different weapons and skills. It is such a beautiful game!I really recommend you this amazing game!!! It`s worth all the money. Get goo goo alu

author: Graint
review: This game is a simple masterpiece. I definitely have put this game as one of my most favorite games of all time.  The one problem is that is was the best co-op experience I have had in a game in a long time, or maybe ever. Now that I have played it I feel that finding another co-op genre game will be of high expectations, and on the same level as this. It was a great time if you have a best friend that you love to play games with. The game has many beautiful arcs to play through each giving you new abilities changing the way you play for the better. It has so many aesthetically pleasing moments that you feel you can't stop smiling along with your friend. Purely an incredible time and I loved the game through and through, I definitely recommend.

author: Bubbles
review: I recommend this game for three reasons:1) Unique playthrough - you experience a different side of the game depending on the character you play2) Refreshing game mechanics - changes each level, mini games included3) Cute!However, there may be deal breakers depending on what you are looking for. The story is not compelling. It could even be seen as shallow. I also think it takes the topic of divorce too lightly. The game itself doesn't prove to be challenging...BUT it is still fun. Each level brings a smile to my face as there is some nostalgia involved and the visuals are appealing. I recommend this game for those who are looking for a chill co-op.

author: Medbii
review: I highly recommend this game if you have a girlfriend or "close friend". I played with this girl I've been talking to for a while and after we beat it we officially hooked up. I plan to go long-term with her, we've already agreed to play it again for our anniversaries because not only is it fun game, but it means so much more to us now. 10/10

author: Awesome Rinu
review: Had sooo much fun playing this with my partner, an amazing co-op game. This game is by far the best ever I've had fun playing, there's always something new to be explored and never do we end up doing the same thing again. Everything is so cleverly done and the gameplay is just beautiful. Although I said all of this I'd only give this a 9/10 just cause Cody and May didn't give Hakim a hug in the end ;-; . We all need someone like Hakim in our lives.

author: Heimerdinger
review: I don't think its an exaggeration to say this game is the best two player co-op game ever made.Every level is so fun and unique, and the game is always giving you new abilities so it rarely feels dull.Grab a friend and get this game. You won't regret it.

author: SpongeCakeofDeath

The only thing that gave me the slight uneasiness wAS ThE RED BOOk wiTh the MuStacHe!! >:c i cant wait to play this game again with my bb and reminiscence and laugh through this masterpiece of a game! PLEASE PLAYYY ITTTTT ! :0

author: C4nAbi

author: Sparky
review: One of the best and funniest co-op game I've ever played. 10/10

author: TashBash_97
review: Just finished this game with my boyfriend , and I have to give my applause to the creators of It Takes Two. The game in its adorable way, was a graphical masterpiece :) Every Level you go through was so uniquely thought of , that you wanted to take your time exploring every little nook and corner of this game :) The mini games, the dialogue between the main characters and the story overall kept me laughing in its cheesy way XD Even till the end it definitely left a hidden message to reflect on for me and my partner :) I would recommend this game to anyone looking to purchase this game , especially anyone in long distance relationships.

author: tjwelton05
review: Wow, just wow. This game is amazing. My significant other and I had a blast playing this game and are currently playing through again switching characters. The music was fantastic and really went will the the beautiful visuals. There are so many clever mechanics in this game that it never got boring. We enjoyed every minute! This game has everything. Play through and you'll understand. Well worth the price tag. After playing I just want more, and hope that maybe there can be a sequel or even an expansion somehow. As other's have stated this feels like a GOTY quality game. Also we experienced zero bugs. Well done Hazelight!

review: congrats for GOTY, my first reaction when play this game so incredible from the story,graphic, gameplay, music,puzzle, the joke..bak kata nizam macam main final fantasy xiv online masuk dungeon HAHAHA, when I was young I imagine wanting to really play a game like this with beautiful graphics .. yeah it takes two to make my dream come true.  we love Dr. Hakim  xD

author: marco
review: This is one of the few games that I could fully play with my partner.It required both people to fully engaged, and play strategically.My partner is not a "gamer", but they were able to successfully complete the game, and asked to play again when were had free time.The only other game where we had a similar experience was Unravelled Two.

author: EyebrowBear
review: If I have to describe this game with two adjectives it would be wonderful and beautiful.It has an amazing story, variety of mini-games and game-play, and the graphics? Splendid!From my perspective this is the best co-op game to play with your loving one.I guarantee you It will be a good experience to share and remember together.Oh? You are a completionist too? The achievements are entertaining to get!So.. if you have not tried this game yet.. What are you waiting for?

review: 10/10 would divorce again

review: This game is perfect; it's all about the Origin.After 99 times failing to pass the dice quiz I finally gave up and became a professional D&D Dungeon Master<3

review: Awesome cooperative game. Be prepared to work together.Through the course of the 100% we only fought once.

review: you're forced to kill a cute baby elephant. we almost cried and debated playing further.

author: Jeaniewuu
review: This game was absolutely so breathtakingly amazing! From the story line to the mini games, every moment of it was just *chef's kiss*! The only down side is that it ended!! Still, it's best to play it with someone you get a long with and care about :)

author: Hylander
review: Probably the best coop based game I've ever played. The main game had so much variety to it and every level was more fun than the last. Each chapter has mini-games thrown in to find, these games were pretty refreshing and unlike the main coop aspect of working together they can get very competitive. The game has a unique charm that I honestly didn't expect and I would highly recommend it.

author: Onee-sama
review: It takes two is really special. I could leave it at that, give the game a positve review and go on with my life, but I won't. I want to convey just how good this game is and how much fun my best friend and I had playing it. So this could be a little long.I first saw this game in a trailer last year and immediately thought to myself: "We need to play this!" Especially since the previous game of Hazelight "A Way Out" brought us many great hours of fun. But when I saw that "It takes two" classified itself as a Platformer, I was scared, because I knew that genre wasn't really my friends favorite. Nevertheless we decided to at least play the demo on release. I'm so glad we did. The demo alone was about half an hour to an hour long. (Probably an hour since we just messed around at every opportunity) The first thing we both noticed was, that the game looks gorgeous. The graphics had a particular style between realism and fantasy. Especially later levels really look magical, but I don't want to talk about them too much. You should really try to go into this as blind as possible. To be surprised is half the fun in this game. The second thing we noticed was, that the controls were really tight and snappy. The characters were really nice to control and misinputs were a rarity and entirely our fault, when they happend. With that said, we made our way through the demo, which was the entire first level and at the end of it we were both sold. We didn't know what else to expect of the game. The first level was pretty simple with straightforward mechanics and simple puzzels. When we continued to the second level, we hoped the game could at least stay at this level of quality. OH BOI were we wrong. The game gets continuously better, the longer you play it. Every new level we started, we said to each other: "I can't wait to see what's next!" And a few times in every level we laughed out of pure joy and yelled: "This is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome!!!" Normally you'd expect a game to have highs and lows, but "It takes two" was almost constantly high. With some exceptions. One part in particular just was heartwrenching to go trough. Those who played it will know what I mean, when I say Elephant. Just terrible. But just in a Story-sense. It won't impact my feelings of the game overall. The other aspect, that was a little bit disappoiting for me was the Ending. I won't spoil it, of course. What I can say though was that it just came to suddenly. We didn't even notice that we played the final level. It was just lacking that sense of finale, but that's just my opinion and maybe you see it differently. With that said, I absolutely recommend this game to everyone who wants to spend a good time with their loved ones. With the whole Friend's Pass thing you don't even need to buy it twice, so 40 Bucks is definitely worth this spectacle of a game. "It takes two" set a new bar for COOP-Games for me and I can't wait to see what Hazelight will be working on next. Like I said, this game was really special. Thanks for this great ride!

author: McMunch^
review: All I can say is WOW!!!!! I have been looking for years for a game that takes Co-Op to a new level, This is that sort of game, I'm so AMAZED!!!!Have played for 6 Hours so far and we are still not done, I'm writing this review because I can't hold in all the positive feedback. The game mechanics in this game is beyond my expectations. At first, I found it irritating because of the split screen that the game uses, but later on, I was more amazed. The perfect sync between me and my friend was an easy alternative when trying to explain where to navigate. The story is so far more than good. It might even teach us a thing or two about what we might take for granted. So many real-life memories bubble while playing this game.Considering buying it? Then do it! Worth every penny and I will support the studio for an awesome game !!

author: LilyZleepy
review: Twas best game i play this year :)

author: WhiteDynamite
review: Pros:Game runs so smooth, Im getting 130fps with 1070gtx and ryzen 3700x on high settings.Looks really nice and sharp, very colorful, its like you're in Pixar movie.Character designs are really nice.Voice acting is great, same level as any big budget 3D movie.Gameplay is really fun, every level offers something new.Only one player needs to own copy of the game, coop friend plays for free.Cons:None really, game is worth it.

author: Strawblaze
review: It Takes Two is doubtlessly one of the best coop adventure game I've ever played. From clever boss battles to crazy gameplay twists and detail-rich sceneries to explore, there's an incredible variety of activities from the start to the end, especially as the fantasy setting allows for many outside the box ideas that weren't possible on A Way Out. It keeps getting better and better as you play it, and I can only imagine how hard the developers worked to achieve this. I'm already anxious to see find out what Josef Fares got for us up next.

author: Mister Snizz
review: Increasing the available language options is good, but It Takes Two now needs as much space as Elden Ring. Insanity.A 50% increase in the application size because of a mandatory download of language packs that are useless outside of anyone's chosen language is insane.The game is fine, but I don't have the space on my PC for the update, and can't play it until it's downloaded. So the game I paid for was just bricked by the developers because they didn't make the download optional.Cannot possibly recommend until they sort that out.

author: Cookie
review: One-time, fantastic experience.My favorite thing is that our duo are actually ADULTS, and they act like ones. They sometimes lie, do questiable things just to reach their goal. They are not perfect and it's normal.Only my problem is VFX in this game quite hungry, and can tank you FPS in some scenes.After playing this game, your benchmark for coop-games will shift.

author: fen.exe
review: Эксперименты авторов Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons и A Way Out не перестают утихать, и даже напротив, с каждой игрой лишь набирают, используя весь свой пройденный опыт.It Takes Two - это венец их творения. Непревзойденное кооперативное приключение про женатую пару на грани развода, которая превращается в пару маленьких кукол. А грандиозное приключение призвано скрепить их почти разрушенный брак.Основные места действия - дом наших протагонистов и их задний двор, на которые нам придется взглянуть под другим углом, и не только ввиду небольшого роста героев.Ведь с перспективы наших зачарованных героев и окружающий их мир будет таким же магическим: оживший пылесос, который хочет отомстить за то, что о нем забыли, заменив новенькой моделью, или война белок и ос, которая напоминает классические боевики 90-х, и многое другое, что не раз удивит вас.В нашем большом походе к счастливому браку нам будет помогать Доктор Хаким - Книга Любви, хотя он предпочитает называть себя Книгой Мудрости (да, буквально говорящая книга).По большей части он создает нам проблемы тогда, когда мы не создаем их себе сами. Но его конечная цель - сплотить парочку и научить их решать проблемы вместе, в какой-то момент даже начнется подобие настоящей терапии.Истории в их играх никогда не были на первом месте, но на этом и не делается акцент, так что без зазрения совести его простоту можно проигнорировать. История служит лишь площадкой для веселых испытаний, которые вы преодолеваете с вашим партнером, но все же почерк их первой мрачной игры, про Братьев, местами прослеживается, например, когда мы серфим по внутренностям мертвого кита. Да, порой игра способна преподнести “недетские” сюрпризы, заметно перегибая в жестокости. Но таких моментов за всю игру наберется штук 5-6.Игру намеренно сделали излишне казуальной, в ней даже нет привычной смерти. Если хотя бы один из двух игроков жив, то второй возродится незамедлительно, а погибнуть одновременно - это нужно постараться.Это сделано для того, чтобы привлечь аудиторию, которая далека от мира видеоигр.Но самое захватывающее в It Takes Two - это разнообразие геймплея. Буквально каждые 10-15 минут игра предлагает новые механики, многие из которых достойны отдельной игры.И тем печальнее, что они настолько скоротечны.Сама же игра имеет продолжительность примерно в 10-15 часов, что достаточно много. Определить жанр у It Takes Two даже еще сложнее, чем у предыдущей игры авторов, A Way Out.Если у A Way Out скелет геймплея составлял, по сути, квест с решением задач, то It Takes Two - это скорее платформер с решением головоломок. На самом деле, очень грустно расставаться с этой игрой. Ты понимаешь, что это игра штучной выделки. И при этом реиграбельна, как минимум еще один раз, из-за наличия двух героев с разными способностями, но важно понимать, что сами по себе их способности ничего не стоят. Они обязательно дополняют друг друга. На этом в целом построена вся игра. Вы не можете быть единоличником, это не та кооперативная игра.Оба игрока зависят друг от друга. Взаимовыручка - главный двигатель как геймплея, так и основного сюжетного мотива.Эту игру больше воспринимаешь как игровую площадку, которая возвращает в детство, нежели что-то современное и привычное.Но часто меняются не только механики, но и сами локации. От простой детской комнаты до сувенирного снежного шара. Или сад на заднем дворе, который напоминает атмосферу Grounded, и многое другое.В игре нет коллектблсов, поэтому локации попросту незачем досконально изучать, к сожалению или к счастью решит для себя каждый сам, ведь их наличие могло бы затормозить повествование игры, излишне отвлекая игроков. А с другой стороны, кто-то бы так и так их игнорировал. Но зато по локациям разбросано огромное количество мини-игр. Какие-то хорошие, какие-то скучные, но с задачей они справляются: задержать вас немного подольше в этой замечательной игре, и при этом они ни сколько не портят общую динамику.А вот уровень интерактивности с объектами не впечатляет. Если вспомнить, то в тех же Братьях наши герои постоянно могли взаимодействовать с чем-то внесюжетным. И у каждого персонажа была своя реакция и анимация на это.В A Way Out это повторили и заметно приумножили.В It Takes Two таких моментов можно по пальцам сосчитать, но не будем записывать это в недостатки. Просто хочется хоть за что-то поругать эту игру.Эта игра подойдет абсолютно каждому, даже тем, кто не увлекается видеоиграми. Это отличная игра про семейные ценности и важность взаимоотношений. И такая игра прекрасно проявит себя на семейных посиделках.Вопрос звучит скорее так: "А кому ее вообще можно не рекомендовать?".Наверно, тем, кого не привлекает атмосфера детских мультфильмов. Сюжет здесь максимально прост, как и наши протагонисты. Каких-то интересных твистов здесь можно не ждать, а финал очевиден, даже если вы просто прочитали описание завязки, и это действительно может оттолкнуть кого-то.Но ведь угодить всем все равно не выйдет.

author: applekwisp
review: Played the entire game from start to finish on the Steam Deck. Performance wise, it ran fantastic. There are huge problems with getting origin setup though, and you will have to finagle using the touch screen and onscreen keyboard. I recommend getting whoever you are playing with (hopefully not on Steam Deck) to invite you and having them added on origin prior to playing, or you will have A LOT of problems. Once you get over this hurdle, the game has no issues on the Steam Deck.The game itself is honestly incredibly overrated. I had low expectations considering their previous game A Way Out was a mediocre, completely on rails, forgettable experience. This game is vastly improved in that regard, with a lot control and more variety to the game play. The story, is pretty insulting and likely unrealistic to anyone who has to experience divorce in any way. All of the dialogue is pointless, and frankly annoying. The two main characters are unlikable psychopaths. At one point they in full agreement decided to destroy their daughter's favorite toy, while the toy begged for their life, and forcing her to cry with no evidence that this will even assist them.The coop is OK. In general, one person will be having more fun than the other since both have two different "powers" in every section of the game, but one is always more entertaining and important than the other. There's a chuckle or two hidden in here, and you can get competitive with the basic side mini-game, but it's just an OK game all around. Get it on sale or play it on game pass if you're bored, but this is not a children's game at all.

author: haze
review: I played it with my significant other and we both really enjoyed it. Beautiful graphics, the story is lovely, gameplay is good, minigames are fun and so on.. only thing that bothered me a little is that we had small framedrops here and there with an i7 11700k and RTX 3080. I gotta say that it was mostly in cutscenes so it’s forgivable.Anyways a huge recommendation from me and my gf for this one.

author: B Vitamin
review: After playing this game twice with two different people, I can confidently say this is one of the best co-op games ever created.

author: lone vagabond
review: good

author: bloodgods
review: Incredibly hard to even connect with someone because it forces to use Origin launcher and uses Origin friends list, which is terribly designed garbage from EA.

author: Ruji
review: This game is legitimately built for people with ADHD with the back-to-back minigames and constantly changing gaming environment. One time you could be platforming and puzzle solving another you would be dungeon crawling or playing a third-person action game. There is even a time where it turns into a Tekken duel with the other player steering while one fights on the wings.My girlfriend does not play many games outside of animal crossing or Stardew valley. However, the game introduces a simple and consistent control scheme throughout the game even through the different “game modes” that appeared. It is amazing for non-gamers and played even better when played with a loving and communicative part. (communication plays a key-role as you will see early on)Overall, the music, art, story, and characters all carry a whimsical nature and aesthetic to it. Bombastic bedroom designs, an awesome clocktower boss fight and a wacky saw-style work shed you will never see the same thing twice. The entire tone is very “Disney-like” whimsical, light-hearted, and warm (minus this whole part with an elephant, my god that was horrible).

author: Jello
review: Very wholesome game with so much variety. Me and my boyfriend loved it!

author: Indian Shrekt
review: Don't read this review. Go play the game.

author: Merk
review: Honestly, this game doesn't even know who it wants to be. It feels very light-hearted until you suddenly have to torture a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ elephant for no reason. Also, I don't like how this game basically just says that you need to love each other harder and that divorce is never an option.Nowhere near as good as a way out.

author: Emblem Parade
review: Delightful from beginning to end. This game is crammed with diverse content: every area looks different, plays differently, and has different pacing and challenges. And toys! There is so much stuff here to just fool around with, without you having to worry about how it connects to the story or progress or anything else.  wants you to have fun, to dazzle you with spectacle, awe you with its grand scope as well as attention to detail, and for you to already miss it when the end credits roll (after ~20 hours).Difficulty level is casual to medium, making it accessible to most gamers, though I suspect that complete newbs might find some of it challenging. There's a bit of fast reflex boss combat here, a bit of confusing 3D platforming there, and intentional coordination challenges. But that's why it takes two: an experienced gamer can team up with a newb and help them learn how to, well, play video games.So much stuff! Lots of little homages to classic video games. Lots of silly characters. Majestic environments. Soaring music. Special effects. I can't think of a single moment that was boring or tedious. That said, if I must really dig deep to complain about something, there were  a few areas where affordances weren't very clear or controls were a bit wonky. But, here's the thing: the price of death is small. So, go ahead and try something crazy. Worst case you die, best you die in a hilarious way.There's a story to it, too. It's rather skin-deep, but perhaps it could be meaningful to certain couples dealing with relationship trouble. Everybody else: don't worry about it. It's just a proverbial carrot dangled in front the proverbial donkey that keeps the action going. This is not a story-driven game, but an experience-driven game.Fun, fun, fun. Get a friend and play. Only one of you has to buy it!

author: Cowbedict Cumberbop
review: I can't even begin to say how much I would recommend this game.  It has more charm than most games I've played in my life and definitely doesn't lack in other departments.  The minigames range from fresh spins on puzzles I've seen in other games to completely new ideas I've not really seen explored.  The puzzles are difficult enough to keep you interested but give enough context to figure them out.  I found myself needing to finish the game but saddened that it was over.  The overall tone and visuals of the game make me nostalgic for something that doesn't exist.  The game does a fantastic job of making you feel small but not helpless.  The fact that it only requires you to own one copy while a friend can use the Friend's Pass to play it for free really drives home the fact that it takes two and is intended to be experienced in such a way.  The characters play relatively the same yet take advantage of different mechanics to solve the numerous puzzles, sometimes even splitting apart to tackle different elements.  Boss fights are fair, yet punishing.  Comedy is present, yet doesn't beat you over the head.  You grow together as friends and really learn what it means to COLLABORATE.  This game has permanently become a staple of games I have recommended to people and will continue to do so.  10 Hip Gyrations out of 10.

author: grep
review: I really really liked this game for the first few hours. The worlds are cute and fun to explore, the mechanics are fun and varied, and minigames are great! What a hit!And then you kill the elephant.You are forced maim, torture and kill a cute little elephant toy as she begs for her life (in a child's voice, as if it wasn't disturbing enough) tries to run away and "bleeds" her stuffing. I've never struggled to play something so much. We were on the verge of tears. I cannot stress how deeply unpleasant this sequence is.And the worst part is, the game just forgets you ever did it. The next few levels are once again whimsical adventures in colourful landscapes and we just never talk about the literal elephant in the room ever again. These levels are fun, they're great even, but I really struggled to enjoy them in the shadow of the horrific act the protagonists committed. That aside, the ending comes out of nowhere and kind of sucks too.

review: is a beautiful puzzle game that can only be played with a friend, as the title says.Throughout the game, each character will unlock various weapons and tools that they will use to get back to their human bodies after waking up in the bodies of dolls made by their daughter.This game has beautiful music, environements and a very pleasing and fun gameplay that can be enjoyed with anyone you appreciate ! I highly recommend it. This game doesn't require the two players to buy the game : The second player can either join the one who owns the game through Remote Play Together or through , for free.

author: CoolCly
review: This game is not very good.  The portrayal of divorce is not good.  There's a lot of potential to explore these relationship issues in a healthy and thoughtful way, but this doesn't.  It's just "make time for eachother and you'll be friends again" which is just wayyy to simplistic, even for children.   The characters are annoying and lack any depth to push this narrative even if it was good.It's too bad the gameplay isn't any good either.  It introduces new mechanics in each area which is good - but it never goes past the most basic implementation on how to use these mechanics.  I'd expect each area to ease you into new mechanics with some simple uses and then ramp up to more interesting, challenging, and satisfying uses... but it just does the basic stuff and then moves on.The zones do have a lot of cool visuals - but the shallow story, characters, and gameplay means they are rarely used well, and then we move on quickly.I'll also never forgive this game for the elephant.Thumbs down on this game.  If you are starving for a coop game then I guess you might as well, but it won't be very good.

I was amused, I enjoyed the time i spent with my partner engaging with the story and for that it was worth buying, but i would be just as happy having never started it. it is merely "not a waste of time" and to me that makes most alternatives worth doing instead.

author: Uman Bean
review: It Takes Two is an extremely fun cinematic puzzle-platform co-op adventure. It tells an engaging and humorous story with both heartfelt and serious moments. It is easily my favorite game from 2021 and the fact that I went through the campaign twice is a testament to its replayability and the amount of fun to be had in the game. You and a friend or loved one play as either Cody or May, a husband and wife going through a divorce. Because of this their daughter Rose makes a wish and cries on a so called "Book of Love" turning Cody and May into a clay and wooden doll respectively. They both then go on a journey through about seven main locations with a ton of subsections and worlds to explore. The game takes you through gorgeously crafted environments such as  all experienced through the perspective of a small bug. It Takes Two is about Cody and May's shared journey to heal their broken relationship. Along the way they meet tons of fun characters and unique bosses that are full of life. One of the main ones is Dr. Hakim. He is sort of an antagonist because he's putting them through all of these challenges, but he's also a big source of comic relief, albeit the main characters provide a lot of that comedy already. The game has a heavy dependence on cutscenes to articulate the story but it handles them well. And throughout the adventure it switches between real life and the shrunken down magical world.  The stunning and richly crafted settings that you traverse throughout the game are home to tons of fun minigames to take part in during moments of downtime. There is also a nice level of achievement hunting to be done from finding a ton of special areas and interacting with the world. The levels are further fleshed out by the music which is nothing to write home about but really fits well with all of the locations you explore, furthering the experience as a whole. The main component of this game is its expertly integrated co-op experienced through a split screen. Experiencing the game with a friend or partner brings a whole other level of fun to the experience and it's extremely cool that they made it so that only one person had to buy the game and the other could just join with the friend's pass. The other feature or selling point that truly makes this fantastical adventure stand out is all of the incredibly implemented mechanics differing from level to level and region to region. Each player has a unique item or ability depending on the level that helps them work together to solve puzzles which are seamlessly integrated with fun platforming. The fact that Cody and May have separate abilities makes it fun to play as one character first and then as the other because you get a different experience each time. The amazingly designed stages integrate 2D platforming with 3D and 2.5D.  The only real complaints I have are that Origin was a pain to set up and it was extremely difficult to find my friend initially. The other complaint was that the game wouldn't output audio through my headphones so I had to listen to it through my speakers. Other than that the game's stellar writing, gorgeous environments, entertaining minigames, mix of puzzles and platforming and the memorable characters all make this an easy recommendation leading to a resounding "WHY HAVEN'T YOU PLAYED THIS YET?!"

author: Rosom
review: I am 16This all started in the 6th grade of middle school where I met the girl of my dreams. Her name is Kiara, she was absolutely amazing. I loved her so much even with our ups and downs we still managed to be with each other for 2 years and I have to say, it was the best 2 years of my life. I loved her with my heart and soul but I guess that couldn't keep us together. It was at 8th grade where we broke up and I felt so devastated. I couldn't keep my head up especially with covid-19 quarantine (among)st (us). It was terrible but thankfully with the work of God himself, he brought her back to me, not as a partner but as a friend. Unfortunately I couldn't win her back because she already in the arms of another man. A 7-foot frame, but I swear this man had rats along his back. His name was Bruno, we don't talk about him. All I have to say was he was a terrible dude and I know I was much better. They ended up breaking up.This is where this game gets involved.Current day: It's winter break and I go along to meet my sisters and I come back home with a bit of money. I saw the game was on sale for $20 less, which was my selling point. I had bought the game to bond with her more and thought it would be a super fun time. I told her about this game in advance when I saw it and bought the game for us to play when I got back from my mini trip. I was only gonna be about 3 days gone and she said she was fine waiting for me to get back. Sad stuff, turns out she told another dude about the game and he bought it to play with her when they both knew that I had bought the game to play with her first. I get back from my trip and the first thing I see on her discord status when I get on my computer, is "Currently Playing: It Takes Two Friends Pass." I was furious! I had just bought this game to play with her but she went on to play with someone else. I didn't know what to do and went off on her. She completely turned the tables and blamed it on me. I was flabbergasted. I couldn't believe she had done such atrocity. I blocked her instantly out of my fury. I didn't know what to do and I was heartbroken.There I was sitting alone in the dark. Not being able to comprehend what happened. It was just me, my bright ass pc (Ryzen 5900x, 3080 TI, 64 GBS 3600 MHZ Ram, NZXT Kraken Z63 AIO and NZXT AER RGB Fans that I all got for Christmas in a Lian Li O11 Dynamic XL computer case BTW) and It Takes Two which I had no one to play with. It was a sad day for me until I talked to my friend about the situation. He had offered to play the game with me and I was rambunctious, and ecstatic of his offering. I instantly accepted his offer and started playing with him, I realized I didn't need to play with that woman that had did me dirty and I could have fun in other ways.In conclusion, this game is actually pretty good and holds up pretty well. It even holds a special place in my heart because of all this.Thanks for reading my review on It Takes Two :) Edit:I am now playing this game with my new girlfriend and I have never been more happier in my life. She is everything to me and I'm glad I got to play this with her, I no longer have any regrets for buying this game because playing this with her made her so happy and seeing her happy makes me happy.

author: Raio
review: The first meaningful review I've left on a steam game ever.I've been on Steam for a very long time, and it's very rare that I will actually come and leave a review on a game I like or dislike for that matter.This game was absolutely amazing. My girlfriend and I played it together, and I can't tell you how much we both loved playing this together. Every moment, every level, every mini-game and every little detail was absolutely astounding. This was hands down the best game that I've ever played, ever. I have THOUSANDS of hours on multiple games that I've played on steam; however, this game was definitely the most meaningful and loving game that I've ever played. I cried a lot for the ending, and I hope in the future we all can see more from this wonderful team that created this game.I will also say, this is the first time I made sure to look at every name in the credits of any game that I've ever played. I just can't express enough of how much this game really meant to me. This was amazing in every single way. Thank you so much to the developers and every person who helped create this absolute masterpiece. Amazing job, and thank you very much for the work y'all put into this.I seriously can't express how much I appreciate the work that went into this game. Every level was something unique and seriously astounding in the detail and level design that went into this. We had fun EVERY.SINGLE.MINUTE that my girlfriend and I played together.THANK YOU SO MUCH to this entire team! I guarantee this entire gaming community that has experienced this masterpiece loves the heck out of you guys for this beautiful work!

author: Pablo
review: When It Takes Two was released, I took a chance. I bought the game without knowing if I was going to play it. This game is multiplayer only, and to me, most of the people I know of that loves video games lives on other countries, on other time zones and they are busy as well. This is the life I choose, this is my passion, and it is a lonely one. But this game has something to say about that: if you buy it then you get a friend’s pass and the second player plays for free…Now, that was something… but i was still out to find the second player, I had to…  and this proved to be challenging, unsurprisingly, but in the end I managed.When I finally got to play with my good friend, I was glad I did. One of the best things about It takes two, comparing it to other multiplayer games is that it is not really competitive as in “I have to kill the other player” but it is more of a collaboration… (if you play the game you will know what that really means) But deeper meaning aside, it is just that: a truly co-op experience between two players. And I mean that: you will laugh, you will cry, you will scream in ecstasy… and you may also agonize… probably putting your “real world” relationship to the test… This game really needs you to communicate one way or the other with your partner, or your friend or whoever is the other person you are playing with.This game shows emotions through the mechanics you play with on different levels.While playing I experienced once again what is it to play with someone that you are in great synchro with, someone that playing with is like flowing effortlessly and joyously even without spoken words… I also played with friends on other time zones and have a great time while doing it. And finally I also played with someone where gameplay was not always in synchro and where communication was not always flowing effortlessly and was even challenging… but funny enough, this was also a time were communication was key, and through communication we had a great time and many laughs while trying to advance and failing and then succeeding (but mostly failing!). This led me to have one of the best times I had in games with a friend since forever.All this while in the middle of a pandemic, where going to someone’s house was not possible… so that made this experience all the more significant. And in all honesty, in a way it made it even more easy and accessible since I didn’t have to physically go to my friend’s house each time we wanted to play.It reminded me once again, on how far video games have come as a way to express yourself and share experiences with others. This was above everything else, a fun game, with so much variety in it: different levels with different mechanics,  each one having their own distinct theme and mood, feeling almost like a new game each time and still managing to keep it all as a one full cohesive experience with endearing main characters and some surprisingly emotional moments.

author: Anomaly

author: Atreus
review: This is the best game I've played this year. The gameplay is top notch. There are fun platforming aspects, a bit of exploration without being ridiculous (while still rewarding you for doing it), fun and varying mechanics, an AMAZING soundtrack, lovely sound and level design, surprises to keep you on your toes, and a great story and characters. review: im in love with this game , i played a way out before this and was looking forward for it takes two since its from the same creators and yes the games looks amazing , the visuals , graphics , story and gameplay all looks so good , everything about this game keeps you playing without Realising how much time you played ! my first time playing yesterday and i played time for almost 5 hours , im excited to finish it and play more , i would highly recommend everyone to get this games without second thoughts just grab it and play

author: Kicks
review: This is easily one of the best games ever made, and definitely *the* best 2-player co-operative game ever made.  It's gorgeous, it's funny, and my partner and I have had an absolute blast with it so far.  You can tell this has been authored with love.  At first I thought the split-screen was unnecessary given we were playing on separate PCs over the internet - but it quickly became important, whilst talking on discord, to be able to see what the other player was doing and give them advice.Additionally the fact that only one of you needs to own the game, and your partner/friend can just use the Friends' pass edition is another cherry on an already well-iced cake.I guess the only way I could not recommend the game, is if you literally have zero friends.  Like, zero. And if that is the case, you have more important problems than whether or not to buy this game.

author: Smartik1
review: I was skeptical at first due to the quality of game released in the past few years, but this took me by surprise.Pros:- Varied gameplay - I can't stress this enough. They constantly keep changing the way you play and introducing new concepts and mechanics so the game really doesn't get old.- Varied environments - Every level is entirely different. Surroundings, movement, weapons, everything changes.- Graphics - Overall the game is visually impressive. Some specific scenes are breathtaking.- Coordination - Unlike other coop games, you really can't solo this one. You need to work together to beat it.- Story - The concept is quite simple, but this game really shows you it is all about the journey. You get to learn more about the characters and how they got to where they are as you play.Cons:- Needs Origin launcher.It looks expensive, but it is definitely worth the money. We got two copies and have no regrets. Not even halfway through the game yet, but really enjoying it.

author: Gory Tundra
review: This is one of the greatest co-op games I have played in a very long time. So the aim of the game is to complete all the obstacles to get back to your real body. The story behind the game is really nice and in some instances it can feel close to home as I am sure everyone knows someone in a broken home. Visually the game is incredible. The art-style is really beautiful and you can see all the effort that went into making this game. The music and sounds in the game is really fitting to all the circumstances and situations you are in. All the characters have their own stories and their own personalities show in everything you do. Throughout the game you get to know each character better.Overall I think everyone needs to play this game. It is extremely fun and I am sure that it would help a lot of relationships and get you to think a little further.

author: Dreaderz
review: It Takes Two. A game, which can be interpreted quite literally, it takes two players to complete the game. Although the game isn't that long, it's the experience that makes this game worth while. Incredibly fun to play, whilst you work together to overcome obstacles, you can also go head to head against the other player in minigames scattered throughout the world of It Takes Two.The story is where the game has its roots, but the gameplay mechanics and puzzles is where the game really shines. You play as parents of a little daughter called Rose and about to get a divorce. But, due to a final wish from Rose, you are given a chance to change that by working on your marriage. To fix it, the marriage does require 2 people to work on the relationship. It takes two to fix problems. It takes two to overcome obstacles. It takes two.Highly recommend this game!!

author: Ltm1900

author: TwerpOco
review: Pros:+ Great visuals+ Incredible world-building+ Extremely polished, encountered almost no bugs (good job devs/QA!)+ Fun extras. A lot of the areas you get to explore are very detailed and fun to explore.Cons:- Forced split screen that serves no purpose 90% of the time. It's a tragedy really, since the environments are so well crafted and imaginative but you can only ever see a small sliver at a time due to the forced split screen. This could have been a really cool mechanic that no other game has attempted, but instead it was a massive hindrance.- Boring. Most of the "co-op" was pulling levers at the same time. The mechanics you see in the trailer all pretty much feel the same once you boil them down, and most of them feel quite repetitive after the first five minutes in a level.- Forced writing, bad dialogue, and annoying unfunny characters. The game's plot is so contrived, it's almost insulting. I honestly have a hard time believing the writers had any personal experience with divorcees due to how cliche and uninteresting the story was. On top of that, the characters are annoying as can be - constantly throwing shade at each other and really ruining a lot of the fun moments. These people are NOT easy to root for either. At one point, they even brutally  in order to make their daughter cry, then show absolutely zero remorse for their actions (the game doesn't give you a choice not to , by the way). Most importantly, by the end of the story the main characters still have not had any real self reflection or character growth.- May tells you exactly what to do. All. The. Time. She'll ruin even the most obvious puzzles IMMEDIATELY because she opens her obnoxious pie hole to spell it out for you. "Pull that lever, Cody! Get the key, Cody! Put the key in the hole, Cody!"- Between some of the crude humor sprinkled in, the game's theme, and the absolutely brain dead puzzles, I seriously can't tell who the intended audience is. It's definitely not meant for kids - or is it? A majority of the puzzles take absolutely zero brain power, but the game itself has a fair amount of adult themes that would be lost on a kid. Playing with a friend can get awkward, but I definitely wouldn't want to play this with a significant other. So if it isn't for kids, it isn't for friends, and it isn't for couples, then who is it targeted towards?Overall, this game was a decent experience, but it's definitely not worth the $40 asking price.

author: Dusk
review: Ok, so, I have mixed feelings on this one.  I played this exclusively with one other person, and I played as May.To be totally fair, I understand why this game is as popular as it is.  It's got incredible mechanics, there are times where they throw the visual style and take it to gorgeous extremes.  It also never gets dull, as the game is constantly throwing new mechanics at you and swapping out the old ones roughly around the time where they outstay their welcome.  It does a little too much handholding on the controls for my tastes(yes, for the 100th time, I know F grapples objects), but given the amount of mechanics that this game throws at you, I can totally understand why they decided to tell the players what button does what every time any interaction comes up.  The variety of the minigames is also really good and pretty well paced out to give you a break from the campaign nature of the game of going from point A to point B.Now, for the minor downsides.  You need to make an EA account to play this, that does annoy me.  But it's an EA game, so whatever, I got over it.  I initially had some issues launching the game at all, but apparently something went wrong with the initial installation.  Uninstalling and reinstalling the game got around that issues and the two of us had very few technical issues throughout the rest of the game.  As for some of the sections.  I don't understand what control scheme you are supposed to use for this.  Both me and my friend used KBM, which I feel really served us well in the shooter portions of this, but some of the isometric and top down sections really did not suit themselves to the KBM control scheme.  There were portions where I had to hold down W and tap D to really get the correct average direction to not fall of bridges, not to mention the dash had really weird angles to try and land on the correct platform.  My partner also appeared to be having similar problems with the teleporting mechanic, but I can't comment too much on that because I didn't play Cody(and I'm not planning on going back to this to do so).All of that would be fine, and the upsides far outweigh what I've posted so far.  The issue is the story.  Oh boy the story is... how do I put this?  You know that meme that was going around where people would constantly say "Better love story than Twilight"?  Well, I can't make any comparisons to Twilight, never saw it you see.  But you could take every one of those memes and put the text "Better love story than It Takes Two" and it would absolutely be correct.The story was kind of "meh" at the start.  Ok, two people who are getting divorced get Isekai'd into dolls and basically a world created by their past mistakes.  We have a weird "antagonist"(although not really?  This game doesn't have a true antagonist, which is another problem in of itself) of a book that has them going through challenges to get them back together for love or whatever.  They go through and try to figure out how to return to normal.  For some reason Cody "figures out" that since Rose's(their daughter) tears caused them to go into this world, they must be the key to get them back, so they run off and try to get their daughter to cry on them so that they can go back to normal.  It's a really weird leap of logic and the characters honestly have no reason to assume that this is true.  Spoilers from this point on.Then they get to the castle level.  Rose has a toy castle that they get to, and they decide the the best way to get Rose to cry is to kill the queen of the castle.  Queen Cutie, Rose's toy elephant.  They go up to the elephant, and brutally destroy her, limbs ripping off and Cutie begging for her life.  This goes on for maybe... 2 minutes or more?  All with both players needing to press buttons to continue the sequence.  May and Cody are horrific people for doing this, and even if the rest of the story would have been tolerable, it is all soured by the fact that THIS is the first thing that they agreed they should do.  They did comment that they felt like horrible people, but neither of them even remotely thought "Hey, maybe we shouldn't be doing this?" and that speaks volumes of their characters.  Shocker, Rose's tears don't work, and they are stuck as dolls.  They deserve it.And then they go to therapy.  It's whatever, probably would be pretty decent if it wasn't completely overshadowed by the previous scene.  It ultimately boils down to Cody and Rose need to find their passion or whatever.  It's from this point that I will take a break from what is going on to our two "protagonists", and describe how Rose has been seeing all of this.  Everything has basically been life as normal for Rose, she's more or less been left all on her own and trying to deal with the fact that her parents are getting divorced.  Her age is never stated I don't think, but she's like 10 maybe?  Her parents bodies are still in the house, but they are just kinda sleeping for Rose, she's got no idea any of this magic stuff is happening to her parents.  She goes to her dad and he's just sitting upright at his desk, just sitting there with his eyes closed.  She tells her dad about the book she's gotten and she thinks it would help the marriage.  Her dad doesn't respond(for reasons obvious to the players) and Rose eventually leave, but what really stands out to me is that Rose never left the entrance of the room to go and actually see him.  This all happened with Rose talking to her dad from the doorway.  She eventually leaves the room, but she never approaches her dad.  She also does the same thing with her mom as her mom is sleeping on the couch.  Rose leaves her alone because her mom must "have that headache again".  She does approach her mom to play her favorite song when she finds the vinyl recorder up in the attic, but Rose takes a look at what is going on(and has been going on since almost the start of the game) and makes the conclusion that she is the cause of the divorce and runs away from home.  Like what?  Ok, I can understand that she's not entirely thinking clearly because her parents told her that they are getting divorced, but shortly after that, both of your parents completely stop responding to the outside world, and she doesn't consider that they might be sick or injured?  She has conversations with them were they(from her POV) are *completely* ignoring her and have gone catatonic, and she doesn't think that something is horribly wrong with them?  The only way that I would believe that to be true would be if she has been neglected for a very, VERY long time.  And that just makes me consider that it might be better if she were to run away to a friend's house or something.  At least then she might be able to get some help.  Just utterly heartbreaking how this implies what's been going on before the game even started.Returning to Rose and Cody(what? did you think my complaints about the story were done yet? Almost) they are going through therapy, slowly learning to get along again, but the real kicker for me is the final cutscene.  It is revealed(or at least HEAVILY implied) that the only way that Cody and May could possibly get back to normal is to kiss.  I will be honest, I was furious with the game after that scene.  I know somebody who was in an abusive relationship.  Like a real life threatening situation she was in.  So what, somebody like that is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the situation that this game brings up?  Honestly, if some people go through this scenario, the right call could EASILY be to stay that way, and run from your abuser never to return.  Once you make it even a few houses over, you would never be found by your so called "partner", and the abuser would effectively be dead in the real world, never to prey on anyone else.It's a real shame.  To have such fantastic visuals and mechanics linked to such an abysmally bad story.  This game is the worst tragedy I have ever seen in every way.

author: Gamer Gaming
review: It Takes Two is larger-than-life director Josef Fares' third outing, taking the co-op-focused adventure engine of his previous game, A Way Out, but ditching the po-faced action movie pretensions that made it unintentionally funny, in favour of hyperactive fantasy spectacle that players can easily engage with on the same emotional wavelength. As before, anyone can download It Takes Two for free, and play it with anyone who buys the full game and invites them.The game starts with the central duo, May and Cody, mentioning their upcoming divorce during an argument. Unfortunately, their daughter witnesses the whole thing, and her sadness kick-starts the "magical 12-hour couples' therapy adventure" stage, which will be familiar to anyone who has undergone divorce proceedings before. May and Cody spend most of the game as strange little voodoo dolls their daughter made, solving puzzles and fighting household objects while searching for a way back to their world. They're frankly bullied into this by a magical Hispanic marriage guidance book called Doctor Hakim, who won't leave them in peace until their relationship is fixed. His design and accent will be seared into your mind if you've seen the trailer, but I didn't find him quite as funny and engaging as the trailer promised. In fact, he can't outshine Josef Fares himself, who for our money would have been the best character for this role.May and Cody themselves are difficult characters to write, caught between being disillusioned former lovers and stand-ins for the presumably-friendly players. The writers resolve this by making them readily cooperative throughout, taking a little time to bicker during cutscenes, but working towards "destructive" objectives in the hope of just returning home quickly, before Hakim pushes them into more "constructive" activities that might actually repair their relationship. The drama peaks at an expertly executed, unbearable scene halfway through, even more powerful than A Way Out's grand twist. From there it's a fairly uncomplicated journey down to a simple but heartwarming ending, but the excellent art and gameplay pulled us all the way to the end even when the story didn't.May and Cody are likeable enough characters but It Takes Two will really be remembered for its level design. It's a whirlwind tour of beautiful, fun environments, including a perilous giant workshop, a grand cardboard fortress and a time-twisting clock tower. In every area you can expect some combination of chase sequences (Cody is pretty much always driving, if you like that), combat (with plenty of fun bosses), rail-grind sections, platforming sections, QTEs, well-hinted puzzles, 1v1 minigames, Easter eggs and smaller attractions where you can have a little break. There's often a section where gameplay will shift in reference to another game, but the default is acrobatic third-person platforming that heavily reminded us of NieR: Automata (by no means a complaint).Each location is a magical version of some area of May and Cody's home, so it holds some significance to their lives, though if you're expecting deep environmental storytelling you won't quite get that, as the characters tend to exposit the meaning behind everything. This is a good choice really, as you have two cameras on screen and are communicating with your partner, so we always got what was going on even when our attention was a bit divided.  Every location comes with its own pair of complementary abilities, which are fun enough to use for the game to be worth replaying later from the other character's point of view. You could make whole games out of each environment and pair of abilities, but I presume Fares gets bored and wants to move on every 90 minutes, so everything changes up again. The levels and abilities are so varied, and often so exotic that we weren't sure whether the artists or the programmers had more work to do, but the game is visually gorgeous and technically brilliant from start to finish.This is the kind of game you'd want to play with a friend or loved one, and it's likely one of you won't be a gamer. The game is relaxed and forgiving enough for non-gamers, though not a good first game - from the start, it assumes some gaming competency which might be best acquired without the pressure of your partner waiting for you to get your act together. The awkward design of some bosses and action sequences had us wipe out a few times even though we're pretty experienced, weakening some of the spectacle, but at least you can be sure you'll be challenged at points. It's also not for young children, despite looking like a Pixar movie.It's rare for EA to invest in something with this much heart; this much creativity; this pricing scheme. This triumph for Hazelight Studios gives me the impression that some part of EA is still motivated by games, not just money - surely if it can do that, it's worth checking out. Our average score for this game was 95%.

author: Ryock
review: It Takes Two does a lot of things right. Engaging level design, thematic maps, interesting puzzle mechanics, and a two-player system that feels like it requires two people to complete. There are too many two-player games where it's one player leading the charge while the other lags behind as deadweight. This isn't one of them.However, for as intuitive and fun the gameplay itself is, the story is absolutely miserable. Someone called it the "divorce speed run," and I wish I could say that's what happens in the end. Cody and May, the two main characters, are terrible for each other. They emerge from their trials the same toxic people that they went in as. They use and manipulate every side character they meet along the way for their own gains, no matter the cost. There's also this constant mood shift between, "We're going to die!" and "We can't die! Get in there!" It's conveniently scary when the story wants it to be. Since you can't die, there's no real urgency to the game; no real risk. I wish I could recommend this game. I played this to the finish with my SO and it left us both feeling empty. I want more two player games that utilize interesting systems. But I don't want the story to suffer for it.

author: Viper
review: Could be a spoiler, but doesn't really matter.This game is about murderous couple slaying both living and humanized object just to make their one and only daughter cry.Including mutilation of the daughter's favorite doll(living and talking) before murdering it.Then they never looked back at their daughter until the end of the game. THE most psychopathic parents ever, under the brainwashing process of a Latino book who is forcing a relationship.Very very horrible story line. Well, other than that, the storyline is intended to be heart-warming and it is.The co-op playing experience was nice. Awesome game design too.Easy for those who play action game regularly, a bit challenging to those who are not so familiar with aciton platformers.If you have someone else to play with, go ahead and try it!Play time is about ~11 hours.

author: wizcreations
review: An amazing, spectacular, asymmetric cooperative narrative journey! A young girl mourning the news that her parents are planning to divorce prays to a Book of Love to make her parents friends again. Her tears take her parents' consciousnesses into two dolls that must work together to find a way to become human.  Along the way, they rediscover what attracted them together, learn what came between them in their marriage, and realize the other person brings something unique and special to the family relationship. At its core, It Takes Two is not a game for children, but rather a deep emotional discussion about love, relationships, family dynamics, and raising children, all expertly woven together into a fantastic adventure that continues to bring new challenges and mechanics to the players.The developers somehow managed to merge a superb narrative with highly varied and fun gameplay such that neither takes second stage to the other.  Each area presents the characters with new unique yet compatible abilities, requiring them to collaborate to overcome obstacles and enemies they face along the way. The world is filled with detail to give the feeling that you really are doll-sized creatures exploring your own backyard, play room, attic, and more.  Also spread throughout the world are 25 mini games included for no other purpose than to give a short competitive diversion. These are fun to find, fun to play, and show that little bit of extra effort the developers put into the game to make every bit of it fun.The game is never too difficult to proceed and never too challenging to feel hopeless. The characters have infinite lives and a great checkpoint system that never requires you to repeat significant parts of any level. I believe gamers of all skill levels would find this game tremendously fun.

author: Enkufka
review: After 7 hours of play and reaching a certain scene, I can say this game is categorically Just Fine and no better than any other coop game out there.I've found the gameplay to be neutral, and the level design and animation are amazing, some of the areas are absolutely delightfulbut the writing is awful. The two lead characters may just as well be the same person played in two different ways despite all the protestations that they constantly make about being two different people with very different problems. It doesn't feel like a game for kids, it doesn't feel like a game for adults, it feels like a game for people who think quips are equivalent to good writing.

author: Biddies
review: This game has honestly blown me away and is hands down one of the best all around games I've ever played. A buddy and I are 11 hours in to our very first playthrough and can't help but just stopping everywhere we go to say wow. The art style and game/puzzle design have completely blown us away. There's so much to discover and enjoy.I highly recommend picking this up, playing it with your best friend and taking your time with it. It's an experience like none other and this is coming from a gamer with over 1000+ titles on Steam alone.

author: Monsieur Toad
review: Really cool and original game!Pros: - Innovative gameplay with ever changing fun mechanics.- Really well made levels, fun to explore with hidden minigames, easter-eggs, details.- Sound is good (although balanced a bit low even at 100%).- The versus challenges are fun and varied.- You can invite someone to play with you for free with just one game copy with the Friend's Pass.Cons :- While each chapter has some nice and funny moments, the general story felt a bit meh and cheesy (although not as much as we expected). But you can easily go past that and just enjoy the ride.- A bit short maybe (around 10-15h depending on how much you explore). We were expecting maybe another level (or two!) at the end.Highly recommend if you've got someone to play with!
